<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>
<emph render="bold">
Ken Lindsay (1923-2001)
</emph> was a founding
partner in the Challenge Jazz Club, the first sizable jazz club in London after
World War II. As a jazz and folk enthusiast, Lindsay was connected with the
jazz revival and folk movement of the 1950s in the United Kingdom, and made a
career of promoting such musicians and organizing performances. Lindsay also
worked for the International Bookshop where he oversaw the department that
would import records from America and Europe and sell them by mail. This was
the period during which he established a correspondence relationship with Woody
Guthrie. Lindsay went on to work for other record shops and continued to manage
bands, lecture on music at universities, and write articles for such music
publications as
<title>
<part>Melody Maker</part>
</title> and
<title>
<part>Music Mirror</part>
</title>.</p>
<p>
<emph render="bold">
Woodrow Wilson "Woody" Guthrie
(1912-1967)
</emph> was a singer, songwriter, and social activist who
influenced twentieth-century American music and culture. Having lived through
the Great Depression, the Dust Bowl Migration, World War II, and the political
upheavals that resulted in the labor union movement, Guthrie called upon these
experiences as he expressed the plight of common people through his songs,
prose, and poetry. He was a seminal figure in the folk music revival of the
1950s, and his songs and philosophy had a profound impact on society and on
contemporary musicians such as Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical History</head>
<p>Mary Sheppard Burton was born in 1922 in Salisbury, Maryland. Burton,
who became a textile artist and teacher, was no stranger to the art as a child
since both her great grandmother and grandmother were rug hookers. From 1973 to
1988 Burton taught classes on designing, dyeing, color theory, hook art and
traditional hooking techniques at various schools and colleges throughout the
United States. Occasionally Burton also taught private classes at her home in
Maryland. Her students were diverse, from ninth-grade students to adults as
well as the mentally challenged. The individuals who studied under Burton were
not only based in the United States but also came from England and Israel.
During this period she lectured extensively and exhibited her pieces throughout
the United States, Canada, and Japan. Burton was instrumental in developing the
guidelines and standards for rug hooking and judging hooked rugs at local and
international competitions. </p>
<p> In 1981, Burton’s dedication and love for the art led her to research
the hand dyeing of textiles and the color retention of dyes by experimenting
with vegetable dyes used by earlier generations. She experimented with the
different effects that light has upon yarn. Burton used dyeing techniques that
were not commonly used by textile artists. Burton studied the historical
origins of rug hooking, starting her research at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
in New York, continuing at the Textile Museum in Canada in 1996, and in Nova
Scotia in 1997. </p>
<p>In 1994, Burton co-founded the International Guild of Hand-hooked Rug
Makers (TIGHER) and in 1996 was awarded an antique pewter loving cup for
outstanding devotion and service to the organization.</p>
<p>For her outstanding accomplishments in the art, Mary Sheppard Burton
has received many awards. She was the first non-Canadian recipient of two of
the highest awards given by the Ontario Hooking Craft Guild: Best in Show for
Creativity and Craftsmanship and Best in Show for Artistic Presentation of Work
and Originality.</p>
<p>In 2002, she co-authored a book on creativity in textile arts,
<emph render="italic">A Passion for the Creative Life: Textiles to Lift the
Spirit, </emph>with Mary Ellen Cooper. She died on July 1, 2010. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Notes </head>
<p>Paula Morin is a photographer and oral historian specializing in the photography of wild horses of
the Great Basin region of the American West. For more than a decade, she has studied wild horses and conducted interviews about the horses' impact on the ecology and cultural landscape of Nevada.</p>
<p>Born in Hollywood, California, and raised in San Francisco, Morin’s admiration for horses was first inspired by her father, who was raised in Montana. They attended many horse races and polo matches during her
childhood. Morin graduated magna cum laude from Southern Oregon University and later pursued post-graduate
studies in photographic history and cultural anthropology. She became an independent photographer and field researcher and pursued an interest in the nineteenth-century
technique of hand-painted black-and-white photography.</p>
<p> In 1999, Morin received a Rural Community Arts Assistance Grant from the National Endowment for the Arts and the U.S. Forest Service which resulted in the
exhibition Honest Horses: A Portrait of the Mustang in Nevada's Great Basin, supported by the Nevada Arts Council.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Administrative History</head>
<p>In the summer of 1979, the American Folklife Center of the Library of Congress conducted
a field research survey to document traditional folklife in Montana. The survey was
undertaken in cooperation with the Montana Arts Council. The survey team was led by
Barre Toelken, and included folklorists Kay Young, Gary Stanton, Paula Johnson,
photographer Michael Crummett, and photographer Tom McBride, George Wasson, Miiko
Toelken, and Carl Fleischhauer and was conducted from June 28, 1979 to September 15,
1979.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Notes</head>
<p>Oneyda Alvarenga (1911-1984) was a Brazilian journalist, poet, and ethnomusicologist.
She attended the Music and Drama Conservatory of São Paulo and was a student of Mário de
Andrade and Dinah and Claude Levi-Strauss. In 1935 she became the director of the
Discoteca Pública de São Paulo and was a founding member of the Sociedade de Etnografia
e Folclore.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head> Administrative History</head>
<p>The California Folk Music Project (1938-1940) was the result of a joint effort of the
Northern California Work Projects Administration, the Library of Congress, and the
Department of Music at the University of California, Berkeley. The project was
officially sponsored by the University of California at Berkeley and co-sponsored by the
Library of Congress. The New Music Society and the Society of California Pioneers
offered their support and encouragement for the collecting project. The effort also
received some funding from the California State Relief Agency.</p>
<p>Prior to the California Folk Music Project, during 1936 and the early part of 1937,
Sidney Robertson had collected traditional English- and foreign-language music for the
Special Skills Division (KL) of the Resettlement Administration (RA). When the
Resettlement Administration was liquidated late in 1937, and with it, Robertson's source
of funds for recording, she looked for means to continue and expand the scope of her
folk music collecting in her native California under the auspices of the WPA.</p>
<p> Robertson was eager to organize and conduct ethnographic and folk musical research on a
nationwide basis in order to engage in more comprehensive field collecting than was
being done at the time. She discussed her plans with Luther Evans, then Librarian of
Congress and an old friend from Stanford University, who suggested that the WPA in
California might be willing to fund her project. The WPA contacts Robertson made through
Evans became convinced that such an undertaking might best be initiated on a
state-by-state basis. Robertson was promised WPA funding for a prototype of her
collecting plan in any single state, providing she could get the necessary 50%
contribution for the equipment, supplies, and rent required for government projects of
this kind. With such support, she was expected to devise work that could keep from
twenty to forty people employed from the work relief rolls and also be acceptable to at
least three sponsors. Robertson chose to pursue the project in California, where she
sought sponsorship for it through the University of California at Berkeley late in
1937.</p>
<p>It was in the Department of Music at the University of California, Berkeley, under the
chairmanship of Albert Elkus, that Robertson found a willing sponsor for her folk music
collecting plans in California. With Elkus' help, Robertson's project received
university support for space and equipment. And, because she conceived her collecting
project as being of relevance to the fields of anthropology, history, sociology,
literature, and ethnology, Robertson made contacts with interested faculty members in a
variety of university departments, who offered her their support. With the University of
California as an official sponsor, Robertson was then eligible to apply for WPA funds to
hire personnel to assist her in the task of collecting and documenting traditional music
in northern California.</p>
<p>Once WPA sponsorship of the project was established, the Archive of American Folk Song
at the Library of Congress, then under the Music Division's leadership of Harold
Spivacke, agreed to co-sponsor it by providing 12-inch acetate discs for recording the
music and offering cataloging assistance to organize the collection. For additional
non-labor items, which the WPA did not cover, such as catalog cards and travel expenses,
the project received financial support from the California State Relief Agency. In
addition to the backing of official project sponsors, Robertson sought assistance and
support for it from other academic sources. As an advisor on ethnographic standards for
conducting fieldwork, the anthropologist Paul Radin offered guidelines that could be
applied to the collecting of folk music. From George Herzog, Columbia University
ethnomusicologist, Robertson received suggestions on techniques for the melodic analysis
of folk music. Through Herzog's support, she developed a project that accorded
importance, not only to preserving the texts of folk songs, but also to collecting
traditional melodies and their variants so that they could later be analyzed
musicologically. A duplicate set of recordings on disc were given to the University of
California, Berkeley, for the purpose of establishing the Archive of California Folk
Music in 1940.</p>
<p>Although the Archive of California Folk Music was never established, the recordings
became part of the Music Library of the University of California, Berkeley and in the
early 1980s, they were put on permanent deposit in the Stanford University Archives of
Recorded Sound. The Music Library at the University of California, Berkeley, also
retained copies of administrative documents, English translations on folk music,
material on music in the California missions, lists of California songsters and hymnals,
song texts with references to California, material on Portuguese, Spanish and Latin
American folk songs, and sketches, scale drawings, and tracings of folk instruments.
</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>George Korson, folklorist, journalist, and labor historian, was born in 1899 in Ukraine,
and came with his family to the U.S. in 1906. He began his working life as a journalist,
and subsequently wrote several books on the songs and folklore of coal miners in
Pennsylvania and West Virginia. Korson was an advocate for the rights of miners and
improved working conditions for them. In 1957 he was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship to
write the book <title>
<part>Black Rock</part>
</title>. He was a president of the American Red Cross,
served three terms as president of the Pennsylvania Folklore Society, and was elected a
Fellow of the American Folklore Society in 1960. He died in 1967.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Bess Lomax Hawes (1921-2009) was a folklorist, teacher, musician, writer, filmmaker, and
folk arts administrator. Named for her mother, Bess Brown Lomax, Jr. was exposed at a
young age to folk music performance and fieldwork through her father, John A. Lomax, and
brother, Alan Lomax. As a teenager she transcribed music from field recording sessions,
and provided assistance to her father, brother Alan, and composer Ruth Crawford Seeger
during their work on <title>
<part>Our Singing Country</part>
</title> (1941), a collection of American folk songs and ballads. After graduating from
Bryn Mawr College in 1941, she moved to New York City, where she performed with the
Almanac Singers, including Pete Seeger, Woody Guthrie, her future husband, artist Butch
Hawes, and others. She moved with her husband to Cambridge, Massachusetts, where she
taught guitar lessons, wrote music and cared for her young children.</p>
<p>In 1952, Hawes moved with her family to California, where she taught guitar and courses
in folklore and anthropology at San Fernando Valley State College (now California State
University, Northridge). As professor, she wrote a number of academic papers and was an
active participant in the California Folklore Society, which she served as president
from 1971-1973. While on the faculty at San Fernando Valley State, Hawes completed her
M.A. in Folklore from the University of California, Berkeley, studying under folklorist
Alan Dundes. She made four films while working in California: <title>
<part>Georgia Sea Island Singers</part>
</title> (1964), <title>
<part>Buckdancer</part>
</title> (1965), <title>
<part>Pizza Pizza Daddy-O</part>
</title> (1967) and <title>
<part>Say Old Man, Can You Play the Fiddle</part>
</title> (1970). </p>
<p>In 1977, Hawes moved to Washington, D.C. to serve as head of the Folk Arts Program at
the National Endowment for the Arts, and stayed on for a fifteen-year tenure. At NEA she
raised the public profile of the folk arts, establishing apprenticeship and other grant
programs to support folk artists with skills as varied as music and dance, basketmaking,
and pottery. A crowning achievement at the NEA was the establishment of the National
Heritage Fellowship program to honor folk artists for lifetime achievement and
contributions to traditional arts in the United States. Hawes traveled widely for her
work at NEA, both nationally and internationally. She wrote several books: <title>
<part>Step It Down</part>
</title> (1972), co-authored with Bessie Jones; <title>
<part>Brown Girl in the Ring</part>
</title> (1997), co-authored with Alan Lomax and J.D. Elder; and <title>
<part>Sing It Pretty</part>
</title> (2008), a memoir. In 1993 Hawes received the National Medal of Arts from
president Bill Clinton. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head> Biographical Note </head>
<p>Lena Spencer (born Pasqualina Rosa Nargi, on January 4, 1923) owned and operated
Caffè Lena from its inception in 1960 until her untimely death in 1989. Before she
co-founded Caffè Lena in 1960 with her then-husband Bill Spencer, she gained
experience that would bear fruit during her long years at Caffè Lena as both owner
and jack of all trades: she waited tables at her father's Italian restaurant,
performed with an amateur theater group, and worked at a radio station. Over the
years she built a reputation for the Caffè as the place for serious folk artists to
play. The Caffè had a loyal following over the years, who periodically helped raise
funds to keep the business open. Despite her passing, the Caffè has continued to be
a destination venue for folk music artists and fans of folk music: "good folk since
1960."</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Thomas Bird Hoskins, known as "Tom" in general and as "Fang" to his friends, was a
musician and blues music fan who teamed with Dick Spottswood to locate Mississippi John
Hurt in March 1963. They had heard Hurt's 1928 recordings and, based on a clue from the song "Avalon
blues" ("Avalon's my hometown, always on my mind"), Hoskins went to Mississippi and
located Hurt in Avalon, which began the second phase of Hurt's career in music. Hoskins
managed Hurt for a time, and stayed in contact with the family after Hurt died. Over the
years, legal issues regarding contracts and royalties arose, the last of which was
resolved after Hoskins died in 2002, age 60, in Tallahassee, Florida.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist>
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Born in Dallas, Texas in 1936, Sol Biderman has taught literature at universities in California; Genoa and Naples, Italy; and São Paulo, Brazil. He is the author of <title>
<part>Bring Me to the Banqueting House</part>
</title> and the plays <title>
<part>When Elvis Met Che in Denver</part>
</title>, <title>
<part>To Kill a Mandarin</part>
</title>, and <title>
<part>Unabomber Hotel</part>
</title>.</p>
<p>Biderman's interest in the <emph render="italic">cordel</emph> tradition dates to his tenure at the Faculdade de Filosofia de Marilia in São Paulo, Brazil in the 1960s, when he first began to collect chapbooks and meet the <emph render="italic">cordelistas</emph> who wrote them. In 1970, he donated a substantial portion of his chapbook collection to the Library of Congress (AFC 1970/002), which has continued to acquire literatura de cordel through the Library of Congress Office in Rio.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Dr. Maggie Holtzberg received her PhD in folklore and folklife from the University of
Pennsylvania in 1987. Prior to that she gained a BA in ethnomusicology from Wesleyan
University (1979). She was also a student of the traveling Trailside Country School from
1972-1973. She has written and published multiple books, including <ref show="new" actuate="onrequest" href="http://lccn.loc.gov/2008920539">
<emph render="italic">Keepers
of Tradition: Art and Folk Heritage in Massachusetts</emph> (2008)</ref>,
<ref show="new" actuate="onrequest" href="http://lccn.loc.gov/90024004">
<emph render="italic">The Lost World of the Craft Printer</emph> (1992)</ref>, and
<title>
<part>Portrait of Spirit: One Story at a Time</part>
</title> (1996). She has also produced
and directed documentaries, recordings, and public events, including the film <ref show="new" actuate="onrequest" href="http://lccn.loc.gov/97517897">
<emph render="italic">Gandy
Dancers</emph> (1994)</ref> and the exhibition <title>
<part>Keepers of Tradition:
Art and Folk Heritage</part>
</title> (2008). In addition to serving on and leading state,
national, and regional art and folklore councils and agencies, Holtzberg has managed and
directed folklife programs in both Massachusetts and Georgia.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>The Cooperative Recreation Service was formed as a publishing and distribution center
for kits, songbooks, and pamphlets of folk games and songs from the United States and
around the world by Lynn Rohrbough and his wife Katherine Ferris Rohrbough in the late
1920s. The Rorhboughs first collected songs and dances while traveling as recreation
leaders in churches throughout North America in the 1930s. The publications were sold
and distributed to youth agencies and church groups in the United States and
internationally.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>David Bromberg was born on September 19, 1945, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and raised in Tarrytown,
New York. He is a multi-instrumentalist, singer, and songwriter, and has collaborated with a
a variety of musicians, including John Hartford, Willie Nelson, and Jerry Jeff Walker. Though he is
known for the fingerpicking blues style he learned while studying under Reverend Gary Davis,
Bromberg's music covers various American styles, such as bluegrass, country, jazz, and rock and roll.
During a hiatus from his musical performance career, Bromberg became a violin expert, ultimately
building an extensive collection of American-built violins and opening a violin sales and repair shop
in Wilmington, Delaware, with his wife, Nancy Josephson. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Joseph Charles Mele was born in Hammond, Louisiana. He was a graduate of Louisiana State University, where
he received a doctorate focusing on communication arts. During his career, he held positions at Louisiana
State University, University of Alabama, University of Louisiana-Lafayette, and University of South Alabama
where he spent 27 years as professor of speech, speech pathology, audiology, and drama. He died January 12,
2018, in Mobile, Alabama, at the age of 85.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Barbara Dane was born May 12, 1927, and raised in Detroit, Michigan. She is a folk,
blues, and jazz singer, and co-founder of Paredon Records with her husband Irwin
Silber. Paredon published songs, poetry, and oratory related to social and political
activism. Throughout her life, Dane sang at demonstrations in Washington, D.C., and
in small towns all over the U.S. and the world. During the 1950s and 60s, she
performed and recorded with many great musicians from Earl Hines to Willie Dixon.
She appeared on national TV’s Timex Jazz Show with Louis Armstrong. In 1966, Dane
became the first American musician to tour post-revolutionary Cuba. In February
2018, the Smithsonian Folkways released a 2-CD retrospective, Hot Jazz, Cool Blues
and Hard-Hitting Songs along with her historic folkways LP, Barbara Dane and the
Chambers Brothers. On her 85th birthday, The Boston Globe music critic James Reed
called her "one of the true unsung heroes of American music."</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical note</head>
<p>Gwilym Davies (born 1946) is a collector of folk songs from Hampshire, England. He has recorded folk music
in Hampshire, Gloucestershire, Devon, the United States and elsewhere and has deposited recordings with
the British Library Sound Archive and the Library of Congress.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p> Pete Welding (1935-1995), an authority on blues and jazz music, worked as a writer
and music producer, and was a life-long advocate for traditional blues and
avant-garde jazz performers. He wrote regularly for <title>
<part>Down Beat</part>
</title> magazine, wrote liner notes for albums (including releases by Frank
Sinatra, Memphis Slim, Nat King Cole, Ian &amp; Sylvia, and the Paul Butterfield
Blues Band), and edited books on jazz and blues music. His research for his writings
involved interviews of notable figures across music genres, including Signifyin'
Mary Johnson, John Lee Hooker, Pete Robinson, Howlin' Wolf, Judy Collins, Thomas A.
Dorsey, and others. He founded Testament Records in 1963 as a platform for African
American folk, blues, and gospel performers, and produced records by Quicksilver
Messenger Service, Big Joe Williams, and Jean-Luc Ponty, to name a few. Twice
nominated for a Grammy Award (1973 and 1993), he was posthumously inducted into the
Blues Hall of Fame (1996) in the category known (at that time) as
Business-Production: Media or Academic. His works continue to be widely-cited
resources for music researchers. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Administrative History</head>
<p>The Nevada Arts Council Folklife Program, a division of the Nevada Department of
Tourism and Cultural Affairs, was founded in 1985. The organization administers
grants, produces exhibits and publications, and initiates documentation projects
that focus on the many forms of individual, organizational, and community folklife
across the state of Nevada. The Nevada Folklife Archive existed as a repository for
the fieldwork conducted by folklorists and contractors employed by the agency
beginning in 1985. Folklorists employed by the Nevada Arts Council Folklife Program
include Andrea Graham, Russell Frank, Blanton Owen, Eliza Buck, Jeanne Harrah
Johnson, Anne F. Hatch, Michael Luster, Lesley Williams, Nicholas Curchin Vrooman,
Tamara Layman, Debbie Nolan, Penny Rucks, and Christina Barr, among others.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>The Collector</head>
<p>Linguist and folklorist Juan Bautista Rael, highly regarded for his
pioneering work in collecting and documenting the Hispano folk stories, plays,
and religious traditions of northern New Mexico and southern Colorado, was born
on August 14, 1900, in Arroyo Hondo, New Mexico. His bachelor's degree, from
St. Mary's College in Oakland in 1923, led to a master's degree from the
University of California at Berkeley in 1927. After deciding on a university
career of teaching and research, Rael relinquished his family inheritance in
land, cattle, and sheep to his three brothers and his sister. He had realized
that the wealth in northern New Mexico that most interested him was the vast
repertory of folk narrative, song, and custom that had scarcely been
documented.</p>
<p>While teaching at the University of Oregon, Rael returned to Arroyo
Hondo in the summer of 1930 to begin compiling his famous collection of over
five hundred New Mexican folk tales. By then his work had attracted the
attention of pioneer Hispano folklorist and mentor Aurelio Espinosa, who
invited Rael to Stanford in 1933. Rael completed his doctoral studies in 1937
with a dissertation on the phonology and morphology of New Mexico Spanish that
amplified the dialectological work of Espinosa with the huge corpus of folk
tales, later published as
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Cuentos Españoles de Colorado y Nuevo Mexico: Spanish Folk Tales
of Colorado and New Mexico</part>
</title>.</p>
<p>Well-versed in the historic-geographic theory of transmission and
diffusion of motifs, tale types, and genres, Rael set out on the formidable,
almost quixotic task of gathering all the possible versions and texts of the
tales, hymns, and plays he was studying. The vast majority of tales are of
European provenance, with only minimal local references. He meticulously traced
the shepherds' plays to several root sources in Mexico, and his study
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Sources and Diffusion of the Mexican Shepherds' Plays</part>
</title>
is a standard reference on the subject. His ground-breaking study of the
<emph render="italic">alabado</emph> hymn,
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The New Mexican Alabado</part>
</title>, is also a prime resource.
Inevitably the text-centered historic-geographic approach led more to
collection building than to analysis. It has been left to later generations of
scholars to develop performance-centered studies, but the collections of Juan
B. Rael continue to be an indispensable landmark in the field.</p>
<p>Note: This biography was excerpted from an essay by Enrique R.
Lamadrid. For further information on the collector and the collection, see the
framing essays written by Lamadrid to accompany the online presentation
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Hispano Music and Culture of the Northern Rio Grande: The Juan
B. Rael Collection</part>
</title>. See Folder 16 below.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Background</head>
<p>In January 1893 the French journalist and balloonist Georges Besançon (1866-1934), in
collaboration with the Union Aérophile de France, began publishing a monthly illustrated
revue <title render="italic">
<part>, L'Aerophile</part>
</title> (published 1893-1947). Quickly, <title render="italic">
<part>L'Aerophile</part>
</title> became one of the premier journals of the early history of aviation. The first
years were devoted to balloonists and the importance of meteorology on ballooning (for
example, atmospheric effects on equipment, instruments, and humans). In later years, as
artificial wings, gliders, man- and engine-powered planes were developed, the magazine
brought their stories to the public. The materials in the collection were evidently
assembled by staff of the magazine L’Aerophile.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Herold J. Wiens was born in Shanghang, Fukien Province (China) on Dec. 26, 1912. His ancestors were Mennonites from the Netherlands. Mennonite migration brought the Wiens family to Russia, to the United States and then to China in 1910.</p>
<p>Herold Wiens was educated and lived in China until he was fourteen years old at which time his family moved to Reedley, California. During his formative years in China, Wiens developed a knowledge of Chinese culture, and became fluent in Mandarin Chinese and the Hakka dialect. He attended Reedley High School where he graduated in 1931. He received his undergraduate college education at the University of California (Berkeley).</p>
<p>In 1936, Wiens returned to China for advanced study and research at Yenching University in Beijing. There he studied with several of most noted China specialists from the United States. Before returning to the United States in 1940, Wiens worked at the U.S. Embassy in Hankou and Chungking for two years. During World War II he worked in the American Embassy in Chongqing, returning to the United States in 1946. His war-time correspondence and reports gave vivid accounts of the bombing and devastation in war-time China.</p>
<p>Wiens began graduate school in 1946 at the University of Michigan and completed M.A. and Ph.D. programs, graduating in 1949. His celebrated academic career included a nineteen year tenure at Yale University, three years at the University of Hawaii, and one year at Northern Illinois University in DeKalb. He was awarded Fulbright Fellowships twice, once in 1961 and again in 1964, and he was a recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship. He was one of the most accomplished China geographers of his generation and he educated many young scholars at the three universities where he taught. Professor Wiens died on September 15, 1971.</p>
<p>Herold Wiens’ biography can be found in Adina Wiens Robinson, <emph render="italic">China Beckoning</emph> (Oakland, Calif. : Positive Press, 1991); and Hao-jan Chu, “Biography of Herold J. Wiens,” in <emph render="italic">Biographical</emph>
<emph render="italic">Literature</emph>, 19:6 (December, 1971), Taipei, Taiwan.</p>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Background Note</head>
<p> Founded by Caleb Stillson Hammond in 1900, and formally incorporated in 1901,
the company has been known over much of its history as C.S. Hammond &amp; Co.
Unlike most map publishing in the United States, which was centered in Chicago
at the beginning of the twentieth century, C.S. Hammond began work in New York
City, and the company has continued to maintain its headquarters in that
area.</p>
<p>In the mid-1980s, Hammond led the industry in the development of a
computer-assisted mapmaking system by creating a database that contained the
latitude and longitude of all the geographic features on their maps. The
proprietary database was further enhanced by patented methods for line-smoothing
and name placement and culminated with the publication in 1992 of the first
all-digital world atlas, "Hammond's Atlas of the World."</p>
<p> The company was privately owned by the Hammond family until its assets were
acquired by Langenscheidt Publishers Inc. in 1999.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p> Cornelius Mahoney “Neil” Sheehan (1936- ) is a journalist best known for his
reporting on the Pentagon Papers, a secret Department of Defense study of the
U.S. involvement in Vietnam. Sheehan, when working as a reporter for The New
York Times in 1971, obtained the classified documents from Daniel Ellsberg, a
military analyst employed by the RAND Corporation. The papers revealed that the
U.S. had secretly enlarged the scale of the Vietnam War with the bombings of
nearby Cambodia and Laos, and coastal raids on North Vietnam, none of which were
reported in the mainstream media. The government attempted to prosecute Ellsberg
but the charges were later dropped. In 2011, the Pentagon Papers were
declassified and publicly released. </p>
<p> Sheehan published other articles and books on the Vietnam War, including the
1988 book, A Bright Shining Lie: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam. It won
the Pulitzer Prize for General Nonfiction and the National Book Award for
Nonfiction.</p>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Francis R. Valleo (1916-2006) was an East Asia specialist in the Legislative Reference Service of the Library of Congress, a foreign affairs advisor to Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield, secretary of the Senate, and a consultant specializing in Chinese-Asian affairs.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Solomon Mullin served as a flight navigator in the United States, Army Air Force,
Bombardment Group, 385th during World War II. His unit was based in England and flew
missions over Nazi-occupied Europe. He was awarded the Distinguish Flying Cross for
his service. Solomon was born February 9, 1917 and died January 11, 2015. He resided
in Dunnellon, Florida.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Luther E. Grim was born in 1914 and died in 1964. He is buried in York County,
Pennsylvania.</p>
<p> Dorothy H. Grim was born in 1917 and died in 1996. She was a teacher of the fifth grade
at North Hopewell-Winterstown Elementary School in Red Lion, PA. She obtained the maps
for her classroom by writing to publishers. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Samuel C. Phillips was a U.S. Air Force officer, space agency official, intelligence
agency director, and defense industry executive. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Gifford Pinchot was a conservationist, chief forester for the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, professor of forestry at Yale University, and governor of Pennsylvania.
</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Marshall Ryder was born April 14, 1918 in St. Paul, Minnesota, and died November 25,
2014. Ryder served in the Troop Carrier Command for the United States during World
War II. He was aboard a C-47 that dropped paratroopers from the 82nd Airborne
Division on D-Day, June 6, 1944. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Elmo Neale Pickerill was born in 1910 and died in 1975. He was an aviator.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Bertha Schooler Soh was born on August 7, 1915 in New York City and died July 31,
2006.</p>
<p>Sohn was a cataloger with the Smithsonian Institution Libraries, Washington, D.C., from
1963 to 1987.</p>
<p>Thereafter, she worked as a freelance researcher and translator and
volunteered in the library of the Adas Israel Congregation, Washington, D.C.</p>
<p> She was a member of the Jewish Genealogical Society of Greater Washington.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Organizational Note</head>
<p>The American Broadcasting Company (ABC) was founded in 1943 from the assets of the
National Broadcasting Company (NBC) Blue Network. Television network operations
commenced in 1948.</p>
<p>The Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS) was founded in 1929 as a radio broadcasting
network. Television operations began in 1931 with the establishment of experimental
station W2XAB in New York City. W2XAB received a commercial license as WCBW (later
renamed WCBS) in 1941. Television network operations commenced in 1948.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Comedian, actor, and filmaker Jerry Lewis was born Joseph Levitch in Newark, New Jersey,
Mar. 16, 1926. Beginning in 1946, his partner act with Dean Martin, popularly known as
Martin and Lewis, were successively among the most popular entertainers in nightclubs,
radio, film, and television. Following a professional breakup with Martin, Jerry Lewis
embarked on a solo film and television career from 1957-1971. During this period, Lewis
increased the scope of his work to include screenwriting, directing, and producing,
becoming the total filmmaker, as summed up in his monograph of that title. Sporadic film
roles resumed in 1980. Later in his career, Lewis made a critically acclaimed transition
to the stage, playing the devil in the Broadway revival of Damn Yankees, beginning in
1995. He died August 20, 2017.</p>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1919, Jan. 31</datesingle>
<event>Born, Cairo, Ga.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1939</fromdate>
<todate>1941</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended University of California, Los Angeles, Calif.; first school athlete
to letter in four sports</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1942</fromdate>
<todate>1944</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Second lieutenant, cavalry, United States Army</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1945</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Played baseball for the Kansas City Monarchs, Negro National League</event>
<event>Signed contract with the Brooklyn Dodgers</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Married Rachel A. Isum</event>
<event>First African American to play professional baseball in the twentieth
century; joined the Montreal Royals, a minor league affiliate of the Brooklyn
Dodgers</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1947</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Promoted to the Brooklyn Dodgers breaking the major league "color
barrier"</event>
<event>Rookie of the Year award</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1947</fromdate>
<todate>1956</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Played major league baseball with the Brooklyn Dodgers</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1949</datesingle>
<event>National League Most Valuable Player award</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1950</datesingle>
<event>Motion picture, <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Jackie Robinson Story</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1956</datesingle>
<event>Awarded the NAACP Spingarn Medal</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1957</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Retired from professional baseball after being traded to the New York
Giants</event>
<event>Chairman, NAACP Fight for Freedom Fund</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1957</fromdate>
<todate>1964</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Vice president, Chock Full O'Nuts</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1962</datesingle>
<event>Elected to the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, Cooperstown,
N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1964</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Baseball Has Done It</part>
</title>, edited by Charles Dexter (Philadelphia: Lippincott. 216 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1964</fromdate>
<todate>1972</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Founder and chairman of the board, Freedom National Bank of New York</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1965</datesingle>
<event>Published with Alfred Duckett <title localtype="simple">
<part>Breakthrough to the Big League</part>
</title> (New York: Harper &amp; Row. 178 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1966</fromdate>
<todate>1968</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Special assistant for community affairs to New York Governor Nelson A.
Rockefeller</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>

<part>I Never Had It Made</part>
</title> (New York: Putnam. 287 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1972, Oct. 24</datesingle>
<event>Died, Stamford, Conn.</event>
</chronitem>

<event>Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom (posthumously)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1997</datesingle>
<event>Major League Baseball retired Robinson's number forty-two in perpetuity
(posthumously)</event>
</chronitem>

<todate>1973</todate>
</daterange>

<event>Died, Camp Springs, Md.</event>

<head>Biographical Notes</head>
<bioghist>
<head>Josiah Bartlett (1729-1795)</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1729, Nov. 21</datesingle>
<event>Born, Amesbury, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1750</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Kingston, N.H.; began to practice medicine</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1750, circa </datesingle>
<event>Married Mary Barton</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1775</fromdate>
<todate>1779</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Member, Continental Congress</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1776</datesingle>
<event>Signed Declaration of Independence</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1782</fromdate>
<todate>1788</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Justice, Superior Court, New Hampshire</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1788</datesingle>
<event>Chairman, New Hampshire state convention to ratify the
United States Constitution</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1790</fromdate>
<todate>1792</todate>
</daterange>
<event>President of New Hampshire</event>
</chronitem>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1906, Apr. 19</datesingle>
<event>Born, Vaslui, Romania</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Emigrated to United States</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1928</datesingle>
<event>Naturalized United States citizen</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1929</datesingle>
<event>A.B., College of the City of New York, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1932</datesingle>
<event>J.D., Harvard University Law School, Cambridge, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933</datesingle>
<event>Studied at Moscow Law Institute, Moscow, USSR</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1934</fromdate>
<todate>1937</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Moscow correspondent, <title localtype="simple">
<part>New York Herald Tribune</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Morning Post of London</part>
</title>, and Reuters of London</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1937</fromdate>
<todate>1973</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Chief correspondent and manager of Moscow bureau, United Press
International</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1937</datesingle>
<event>Married Ludmilla Nikitina</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942</datesingle>
<event>First American correspondent to file an eyewitness report from the Battle of
Stalingrad</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1953</datesingle>
<event>First westerner to report Joseph Stalin's death</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1954</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>L'U.R.S.S. après Staline</part>
</title> (n.p.: Gallimard. 254 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1955</datesingle>
<event>Nieman Fellow, Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1962</fromdate>
<todate>1963</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Visiting lecturer, University of California, Berkeley, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1973</datesingle>
<event>Retired from United Press International and moved to Madison, Wis.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1973</fromdate>
<todate>1979</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Kemper K. Knapp professor and adjunct professor, University of Wisconsin
School of Journalism, Madison, Wis.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1991, Apr. 4</datesingle>
<event>Died, Madison, Wis.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<event>Assisted Glenn Theodore Seaborg in writing
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Kennedy, Khrushchev and the Test Ban</part>
</title> (Berkeley, Calif.: University of California Press. 320 pp.)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1987</datesingle>
<event>Assisted Glenn Theodore Seaborg in writing
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Stemming the Tide: Arms Control in the Johnson Years</part>
</title> (Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books. 495 pp.)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1995</datesingle>
<event>Assisted Glenn Theodore Seaborg in writing
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Atomic Energy Commission under Nixon: Adjusting to Troubled Times</part>
</title> (New York: St. Martin's Press. 268 pp.)
</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1856, May 6</datesingle>
<event>Born Sigismund Schlomo Freud, Freiberg, Moravia </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1860</datesingle>
<event>Moved with family to Vienna, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1873</datesingle>
<event>Graduated summa cum laude, Leopoldstädter Kommunal-Real-und Obergymansium,
Vienna, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1875</datesingle>
<event>Changed first name to Sigmund </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1876</fromdate>
<todate>1882</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Conducted research on the nervous system at Ernst Brücke's Institute of
Physiology, Vienna, Austria </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1879</fromdate>
<todate>1880</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Fulfilled compulsory military service</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1881</datesingle>
<event>M.D., University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1882</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Clinical assistant in Hermann Nothnagel's Department of Internal Medicine,
General Hospital, Vienna, Austria</event>
<event>Met and became engaged to Martha Bernays</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1883</datesingle>
<event>Worked in Theodor Meynert's psychiatric clinic, General Hospital, Vienna,
Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1884</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Joined Department of Nervous Diseases, General Hospital, Vienna,
Austria</event>
<event>Began studying the effects and potential medical uses of cocaine</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1885</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Appointed lecturer in neuropathology, University of Vienna, Vienna,
Austria</event>
<event>Received grant to study neuropathology with Jean-Martin Charcot in Paris,
France</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1886</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Established private practice, Vienna, Austria</event>
<event>Married Martha Bernays</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1887</datesingle>
<event>Began corresponding with Wilhelm Fliess</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1889</datesingle>
<event>Traveled to Nancy, France, to study Hippolyte Bernheim's hypnotic
techniques</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1891</datesingle>
<event>Established residence and office at Bergasse 19, Vienna, Austria, where he
would remain until 1938</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1892</datesingle>
<event>Treated “Elizabeth von R.” (Ilona Weiss) in what Freud described as his first
full length analysis of hysteria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1895</datesingle>
<event>Published with Josef Breuer <title localtype="simple">
<part>Studien über Hysterie</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Studies in Hysteria</part>
</title>] (Leipzig: F. Deuticke. 269 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1896</datesingle>
<event>First used the term “psychoanalysis”</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1900</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Die Traumdeutung</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Interpretation of Dreams</part>
</title>] (Leipzig: F. Deuticke. 371 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1901</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Zur Psychopathologie des Alltagslebens </part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Psychology of Everyday Life</part>
</title>] (Berlin: S. Karger. 80 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1902</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Founded the Psychologische Mittwoch-Gesellschaft (renamed the Wiener
Psychoanalytische Vereinigung in 1908)</event>
<event>Appointed Professor Extraordinarius, University of Vienna, Vienna,
Austria</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1905</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published “Bruchstück einer Hysterie-Analyse” (“Dora” case study), <title localtype="simple">
<part>Monatsschrift für Psychiatrie und Neurologie, </part>
</title>18:285-310 </event>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Der Witz und seine Beziehung zum Unbewussten</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious</part>
</title>] (Vienna: F. Deuticke. 205 pp.) </event>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Drei Abhandlungen zur Sexualtheorie</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Three Contributions to the Sexual Theory</part>
</title>] (Leipzig: F. Deuticke. 83 pp.) </event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1908</datesingle>
<event>First International Congress of Psychoanalysis, Salzburg, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1909</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Lectured on psychoanalysis at Clark University, Worcester, Mass.</event>
<event>Published “Analyse der Phobie eines fünfjährigen Knaben” (“Little Hans”
case study), <title localtype="simple">
<part>Jahrbuch für psychoanalytische und psychopathologische
Forschungen,</part>
</title> 1:1-109 </event>
<event>Published “Bemerkungen über einen Fall von Zwangsneurose” (“Rat Man” case
study), <title localtype="simple">
<part> Jahrbuch für psychoanalytische und psychopathologische
Forschungen,</part>
</title> 1:357-421 </event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1910</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Über Psychoanalyse</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Origin and Development of Psychoanalysis</part>
</title>] (Vienna: F. Deuticke. 62 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1912</datesingle>
<event>Establishment of the “Committee,” a group composed of Freud's closest
associates including Karl Abraham, Sándor Ferenczi, Ernest Jones, Otto Rank, and
Hanns Sachs who consulted regularly on issues relating to Freud and the
psychoanalytic movement </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1913</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Totem und Tabu: einige Übereinstimmungen im Seeleben der Wilden und der
Neurotiker</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Totem and Taboo</part>
</title>] (Leipzig: H. Heller. 149 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1918</datesingle>
<event>Published “Aus der Geschichte einer infantilen Neurose” (“Wolf-Man”case
study), <title localtype="simple">
<part> Sammlung kleiner Schriften zur Neurosenlehre</part>
</title> IV (Vienna: F. Deuticke. 139 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Jenseits des Lustprinzips</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Beyond the Pleasure Principle</part>
</title>] (Vienna: Internationaler Psychoanalytischer Verlag. 60 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1923</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Diagnosed with cancer of the jaw and palate </event>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Das Ich und das Es</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Ego and the Id</part>
</title>] (Vienna: Internationaler Psychoanalytischer Verlag. 77 pp.) </event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1930</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Awarded the Goethe Prize by the city of Frankfurt, Germany</event>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Das Unbehagen in der Kultur</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Civilization and Its Discontents</part>
</title>] (Vienna: Internationaler Psychoanalytischer Verlag. 136 pp.) </event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1931</datesingle>
<event>Bronze plaque erected by the city of Príbor, Czechoslovakia (formerly
Freiberg, Moravia) at Freud's birthplace</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933</datesingle>
<event>Published with Albert Einstein <title localtype="simple">
<part>Warum Krieg?</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Why War?</part>
</title>] (Paris: International Institute of Intellectual Cooperation. 61 pp.)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1938</datesingle>
<event>Left Vienna, Austria, and settled in London, England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1939</datesingle>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Der Mann Moses und die monotheistische Religion</part>
</title> [ <title localtype="simple">
<part>Moses and Monotheism</part>
</title>] (Amsterdam: A. de Lange. 241 pp.) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1939, Sept. 23</datesingle>
<event>Died, London, England</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<chronitem>

<event>Born, Crescent City, Fla.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1911</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Harlem, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1912</datesingle>
<event>Attended the College of the City of New York, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1914</datesingle>
<event>Married Lucille E. Campbell (died 1963)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1917</fromdate>
<todate>1928</todate>
</daterange>
<event>With Chandler Owen helped found, edit, and publish the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Messenger</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1918</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Joined the Socialist Party</event>
<event>Arrested for speaking out against American participation in World War I,
Cleveland, Ohio</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Organized the Friends of Negro Freedom</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1925</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Organized the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters</event>
<event>Called on President Calvin Coolidge to protest the lynching and plight of
African Americans</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1925</fromdate>
<todate>1968</todate>
</daterange>
<event>International president, Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1935</datesingle>
<event>Won the right to represent the sleeping car porters with the Pullman
Co.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1936</datesingle>
<event>Founding president, National Negro Congress</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1937</datesingle>
<event>Negotiated the first wage agreement with the Pullman Co.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1941</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Organized the March on Washington Movement</event>
<event>Helped persuade President Franklin D. Roosevelt to issue Executive Order
8802 establishing the Fair Employment Practices Committee</event>


</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1943</datesingle>
<event>Helped persuade President Franklin D. Roosevelt to issue Executive Order 9346
establishing a new Fair Employment Practices Committee</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1948</datesingle>
<event>Encouraged President Harry S. Truman to issue Executive Orders 9980 and 9981
creating a Fair Employment Board and a President's Committee on Equality of
Treatment and Opportunity in the Armed Services</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1951</datesingle>
<event>Conference with President Harry S. Truman led to Executive Order 10210
forbidding racial discrimination by government contractors</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1953</datesingle>
<event>Consultation between Randolph and other civil rights leaders and President
Dwight D. Eisenhower led to Executive Order 10479 reconstituting the contract
compliance agency and placing it under the chairmanship of the vice
president</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1955</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Advised President Dwight D. Eisenhower to issue Executive Order 10590
establishing the President's Committee on Government Policy to enforce a
nondiscrimination policy in federal employment</event>
<event>Persuaded the AFL-CIO to outlaw racial discrimination</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1957</fromdate>
<todate>1968</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Vice president, AFL-CIO</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1959</datesingle>
<event>Founded the Negro American Labor Council</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1963</datesingle>
<event>National director, March on Washington</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1964</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Established the A. Philip Randolph Institute</event>
<event>Awarded Presidential Medal of Freedom</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1964</fromdate>
<todate>1968</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Influenced the passage of legislation establishing the civil rights and the
voting rights acts</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1966</datesingle>
<event>Chairman, White House Conference "To Fulfill These Rights"</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1979, May 16</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1944</datesingle>
<event>Instructor and faculty advisor, Hunter College, New York,
N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1945</datesingle>
<event>Agent, Sam Jaffe Agency, New York, N.Y., branch</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1947</datesingle>
<event>Established Lucy Kroll Agency, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1985</datesingle>
<event>Member, Hall of Fame, Hunter College, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1993</datesingle>
<event>Received Living Legacy Award, Women's International Center,
San Diego, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1994</datesingle>
<event>Sold Lucy Kroll Agency to Barbara Hogenson</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1997, Mar. 14</datesingle>
<event>Died, Glendale, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

W. Va.</event>

Va.</event>

<head>Biographical Notes</head>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Charles Denby (1830-1904)</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1830, June 16</datesingle>
<event>Born, Mount Joy, Va.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1850</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, Virginia Military Institute, Lexington, Va.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1855</datesingle>
<event>Admitted to the Indiana bar; began practicing law in Evansville, Ind.
</event>
</chronitem>

</chronitem>

</chronitem>

</chronitemset>
</chronitem>

</chronitem>

</chronitem>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>David Porter</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1780, Feb. 1</datesingle>
<event>Born, Boston, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1798</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Appointed midshipman, United States Navy</event>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Constellation</emph>
(frigate)</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1799</datesingle>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Experiment</emph> (schooner),
West India Squadron</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1801</datesingle>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Enterprize</emph> (schooner),
Tripolitan War</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1803</datesingle>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Philadelphia</emph> (frigate),
Tripolitan War</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1803</fromdate>
<todate>1805</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Prisoner of war, Tripoli</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1808</datesingle>
<event>Married Evelina Anderson</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1808</fromdate>
<todate>1810</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commandant, New Orleans Naval Station</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1811</fromdate>
<todate>1814</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commanded <emph render="italic">Essex</emph>
(frigate)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1812</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to captain</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1815</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Journal of a Cruise Made to the Pacific Ocean</part>
</title>.
Philadelphia: Bradford &amp; Inskeep</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1815</fromdate>
<todate>1823</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commissioner, Navy Board</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1823</fromdate>
<todate>1825</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commander in chief, West India Squadron</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1825</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>An Exposition of the Facts and Circumstances Which
Justified the Expedition to Foxardo</part>
</title>. Washington: Printed by Davis &amp;
Force</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1826</datesingle>
<event>Resigned from United States Navy</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1826</fromdate>
<todate>1829</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commander in chief, Mexican Navy </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1830</datesingle>
<event>Appointed United States consul general, Algiers</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1831</datesingle>
<event>Appointed United States chargé d’affaires, Turkey</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1835</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Constantinople and Its Environs</part>
</title>. New York: Harper.
2 vols. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1839</datesingle>
<event>Appointed United States Minister, Turkey</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1843, Mar. 3</datesingle>
<event>Died, Pera, Constantinople</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>David Dixon Porter</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1813, June 8</datesingle>
<event>Born, Chester, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1827</datesingle>
<event>Appointed midshipman, Mexican Navy </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1829</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Appointed midshipman, United States Navy</event>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Constellation</emph>
(frigate), Mediterranean Station </event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1839</datesingle>
<event>Married George Ann Patterson</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1842</datesingle>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Congress</emph>
(frigate)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1847</datesingle>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Spitfire</emph> (side-wheel
gunboat)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1849</datesingle>
<event>Commanded <emph render="italic">Panama</emph> (steamer)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1850</fromdate>
<todate>1853</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commanded <emph render="italic">Georgia</emph> (steamer)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1855</datesingle>
<event>Commanded <emph render="italic">Supply </emph>(ship)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1857</datesingle>
<event>Duty at the Portsmouth Navy Yard, Portsmouth, Va.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1861</datesingle>
<event>Commanded <emph render="italic">Powhatan</emph> (side-wheel
steamer)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1863</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Commander, Mississippi Squadron </event>
<event>Promoted to rear admiral</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1864</datesingle>
<event>Commander, North Atlantic Blockading Squadron</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1865</fromdate>
<todate>1869</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Superintendent, United States Naval Academy, Annapolis,
Md.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1866</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to vice admiral</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1866</fromdate>
<todate>1867</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Diplomatic mission to Santo Domingo</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1870</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to admiral</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1875</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Memoir of Commodore David Porter</part>
</title>. Albany, N.Y.: J.
Munsell </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1877</fromdate>
<todate>1891</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Chairman, Naval Board of Inspection</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1885</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Adventures of Harry Marline</part>
</title>. New York: D.
Appleton </event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Allan Dare and Robert le Diable</part>
</title>. New York: D.
Appleton. 2 vols. </event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Incidents and Anecdotes of the Civil War</part>
</title>. New
York: D. Appleton</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1886</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Naval History of the Civil War</part>
</title>. New York:
Sherman Publishing Co. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1889</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Arthur Merton</part>
</title>. New York: D. Appleton </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1891, Feb. 13 </datesingle>
<event>Died, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>David Porter</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1780, Feb. 1</datesingle>
<event>Born, Boston, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1798</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Appointed midshipman, United States Navy</event>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Constellation</emph>
(frigate)</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1799</datesingle>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Experiment</emph> (schooner),
West India Squadron</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1801</datesingle>
<event>Duty on <emph render="italic">Enterprize</emph> (schooner),
Tripolitan War</event>
</chronitem>

Washington, D.C. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1934</fromdate>
<todate>1936</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Navigator,<emph render="italic"> Astoria</emph> (cruiser)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1936</fromdate>
<todate>1937</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Executive officer of naval station and aide for civil
administration, Guam </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1938</fromdate>
<todate>1940</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Executive officer,<emph render="italic"> Pennsylvania</emph>
(battleship) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1941</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Aide to Harold R. Stark, chief of naval operations </event>
<event>Naval secretary at the first meetings of the Combined Chiefs
of Staff</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1942</fromdate>
<todate>1943</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Naval aide to President Franklin D. Roosevelt </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1943</fromdate>
<todate>1944</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commanded<emph render="italic"> Iowa </emph>(battleship)
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1944</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commanded Cruiser Division One in attacks on Japanese
installations in the Aleutian and Kurile islands </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946</datesingle>
<event>Deputy chief of naval operations </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1948</fromdate>
<todate>1949</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Deputy commander, United States Pacific Fleet </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1949</fromdate>
<todate>1952</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Director of staff, Personnel Policy Board, United States Navy
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1952</fromdate>
<todate>1953</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Commander, First Naval District </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1953</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Retired from Navy</event>
<event>Vice-president for client relations, John Hancock Mutual
Life Insurance Co.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1966</datesingle>
<event>Retired from John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1990, Jan. 25</datesingle>
<event>Died, Needham, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<head>Edwin Markham</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1852, Apr. 23</datesingle>
<event>Born Charles Edward Anson Markham, Oregon City, Oregon
Territory</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1857</fromdate>
<todate>1870</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended school in Suisan and Santa Clara valleys,
Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>circa1870</datesingle>
<event>Obtained teaching certificate, California College,
Vacaville, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1872</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, San Jose Normal School, San Jose, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1874</datesingle>
<event>Attended Christian College, Santa Rosa, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1875</datesingle>
<event>Married Annie Cox (divorced 1884)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1875</fromdate>
<todate>1899</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Teacher, principal, and school superintendent in Southern
California</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1880</datesingle>
<event>Published "The Gulf of Night"</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1887</datesingle>
<event>Married Caroline E. Bailey (divorced)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1898</datesingle>
<event>Married Anna Catherine Murphy (died 1938)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1899</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published "The Man with the Hoe," <emph render="italic">San Francisco Examiner</emph>
</event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Man with the Hoe. </part>
</title> New York: Doxey's</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>circa 1900</datesingle>
<event>Moved to New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1901</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Lincoln and Other Poems. </part>
</title> New York: McClure,
Phillips</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1902</datesingle>
<event>Met Florence Hamilton, later his confidential secretary and
lecture manager</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1910</datesingle>
<event>Charter member, Poetry Society of America</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1914</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published with Benjamin B. Lindsey and George Creel
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Children in Bondage. </part>
</title> New York: Hearst's
International Library</event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>California the Wonderful. </part>
</title>New York: Hearst's
International Library</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1915</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Shoes of Happiness, and Other Poems. </part>
</title> Garden
City, N.Y.: Doubleday, Page</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Gates of Paradise and Other Poems. </part>
</title> Garden City,
N.Y.: Doubleday, Page</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1921</fromdate>
<todate>1940</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Poet laureate of Oregon</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1922</datesingle>
<event>Read "Lincoln, Man of the People" at dedication of Lincoln
Memorial, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1925</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Foundation Stones of Success. </part>
</title> Chicago:
Howard-Severance Co.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1926</datesingle>
<event>Publication of "The Ballad of the Gallows Bird,"
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Century Magazine</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1927</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Book of Poetry. </part>
</title> New York: W. H. Wise</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1929</datesingle>
<event>Elected to the Academy of Arts and Letters</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1930</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Songs and Stories. </part>
</title> Los Angeles: Powell Publishing
Co.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1932</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>New Poems: Eighty Songs at Eighty. </part>
</title>Garden City,
N.Y.: Doubleday, Doran.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933</datesingle>
<event>Awarded honorary Literary Doctorate, St. Lawrence
University, Canton, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1936</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Lecture tour in Mexico</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1937</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Star of Araby. </part>
</title>Stapleton, N.Y.: J. Willig
Press</event>
<event>Awarded $5,000 prize by Academy of American Poets</event>
<event>Declared mentally incompetent by a court in New
York</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1938</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Recorded "Edwin Markham Himself," a phonograph album of
his principal poems</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940, Mar. 7</datesingle>
<event>Died, Staten Island, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1910, Jan. 28</datesingle>
<event>Born, Brooklyn, N. Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1928</datesingle>
<event>A.B., College of the City of New York (later City College of
the City University of New York), New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1929</fromdate>
<todate>1931</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Apprenticeship, Eva Le Gallienne's Civic Repertory Theatre,
New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1931</datesingle>
<event>Broadway debut,
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Wonder Boy</part>
</title>, Alvin Theatre, New York, N.Y. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933</datesingle>
<event>Married Stella Reynolds</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1933</fromdate>
<todate>1940</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Instructor, Speech and Theatre Department, Brooklyn College,
Brooklyn, N.Y. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1934</datesingle>
<event>A.M., Columbia University, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>
<event>First major role on Broadway,
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Fifth Column</part>
</title>, Alvin Theatre, New York,
N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946</datesingle>
<event>Film debut,
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Temptation</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1954</fromdate>
<todate>1974</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Appeared in programs of dramatic readings and performances as
part of the Gertrude Clarke Whittall Poetry and Literature Series, Library of
Congress</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1957</fromdate>
<todate>1958</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Adapted, coproduced, and acted in George Bernard Shaw's
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Back to Methuselah </part>
</title>on tour and on Broadway, New
York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>

</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1904</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Syracuse, N.Y., to live with relatives</event>

<datesingle>1910</datesingle>

<part>Coke and Iron Monthly</part>

<chronitemset>
<event>Graduated, First Officer's School in Aerial Photography,
