</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1919</datesingle>
<event>Assigned to McCook Field, Dayton, Ohio, by Gen. William
"Billy" Mitchell; appointed officer-in-charge of aerial photographic
research</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to first lieutenant and appointed officer-in-charge
of aerial photography in the Office of the Chief of the Air Corps, Washington,
D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1924</datesingle>
<event>Reappointed officer-in-charge of aerial photographic research,
McCook Field, Dayton, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1927</fromdate>
<todate>1929</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Appointed commanding officer of the Sixth Photographic
Section, Camp Nichols, Philippine Islands</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1929</datesingle>
<event>Named director of the Army Photographic School, Chanute Field,
Rantoul, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1934</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Promoted to captain</event>
<event>Supervised aerial mapping operations in central and northern
Alaska</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1936</datesingle>
<event>Appointed chief of aerial photographic research and
development, Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to major</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Promoted to lieutenant colonel</event>
<event>Developed the first stereoscopic strip camera</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1943</datesingle>
<event>Married Elizabeth Hayes</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1944</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Awarded Legion of Merit for work at Wright Field, Dayton,
Ohio</event>
<event>Assisted United States Navy with aerial photographic
reconnaissance in England and France</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1945</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Appointed photographic disarmament officer and assigned to
Germany</event>
<event>Awarded Oak Leaf Cluster for the Legion of Merit and the
French Croix de Guerre</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946</datesingle>
<event>Assigned to Bikini Island in connection with atom bomb
testing</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1948</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to colonel</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1950</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Received the Thurman H. Bane Award from the Institute of
Aeronautical Sciences</event>
<event>Granted patent for the flashlight cartridge and camera night
aerial photographic system</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1951</datesingle>
<event>Received the Progress Medal Award from the Photographic
Society of America</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1952</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to brigadier general and appointed director of
reconnaissance, Allied Air Forces in Central Europe, Fontainbleu,
France</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1953</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Retired from air force</event>
<event>Photographic director, Bulova Research and Development
Laboratories, N.Y.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1959</datesingle>
<event>Assistant to the president, Itek Laboratories, Boston,
Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1962</datesingle>
<event>Asked by Gen. Curtis LeMay to make stereo strips of Cuban
missile sites with the stereoscopic strip camera</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1969</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>With coauthor DeWitt S. Copp published autobiography
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Overview: A Life-long Adventure in Aerial
Photography</part>
</title>. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday</event>
<event>Retired from Itek Laboratories</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1976</datesingle>
<event>Inducted into the Aviation Hall of Fame and the International
Aerospace Hall of Fame</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1987, Sept. 20.</datesingle>
<event>Died, Boca Raton, Fla.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<event>Died, Rochester, N.Y.</event>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Note on the Organization</head>
<p>Founded in 1892 and incorporated in 1925, the American Psychological Association (APA),
a professional organization for psychologists, numbered slightly over seventy-two
thousand members as of 1991. The primary purpose of the organization, according to
Article I of the original articles of incorporation, is "to advance psychology as a
science, as a profession, and as a means of promoting human welfare." These objectives
are accomplished through annual meetings, through publication of journals, pamphlets and
books, and through administrative services that strive to improve standards and training
for psychologists.</p>
<p>The chief governing body of the APA is the Council of Representatives, whose members
include representatives from each of the association's divisions and affiliated state
associations. The Board of Directors is the administrative agent of the council and
exercises general supervision over the affairs of the association through interaction
with the executive officer. The board is composed of six council members elected by the
council and six officers of the association (president, past president, president-elect,
recording secretary, treasurer, and executive officer). The executive officer does not
vote.</p>
<p>The administration of the organization is vested in the executive officer, at various
times called the executive secretary, executive officer and chief executive officer, who
manages the central office located in Washington, D. C. Adjuncts to the executive are a
number of specialized administrative offices that support the administrator according to
the interests of the office. For instance, there are offices dealing with educational
affairs, scientific affairs, women's issues, and professional affairs.</p>
<p>Associated with the organization are divisions, committees, and affiliated organizations
that help define the interests of the association. Presently the APA has forty-two
divisions, ranging from "general psychology" and "psychologists in private practice," to
"counseling," "teaching of psychology," "personality," and "family." Committees guide
projects and handle issues ranging from ethical standards to insurance and financial
questions. Some committees are standing bodies; others are continuing or ad hoc.
Committees are established by the council of representatives, board, or other
committees. Affiliates are organizations that have merged or associated with the APA.
One such group represented in the records is the American Association of Applied
Psychologists.</p>
<p>Information on the formative period of the organization is contained in an article by
Samuel W. Fernberger, published in the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Psychological Bulletin</part>
</title> in 1932, detailing its history from 1892 to the early 1930s.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

</chronitem>

and Santiago de Cuba, and became military governor of Santiago de Cuba after
the close of hostilities; held rank of colonel</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1898</datesingle>

general of volunteers</event>
</chronitem>

<datesingle>1899, Dec. 19</datesingle>
<event>Killed in action, San Mateo, Luzon, Philippines</event>
</chronitem>

</title>
(9:439-476)</event>

</chronitem>

<title localtype="simple">
<part>Psychoanalytic Quarterly</part>

New York, N.Y.</event>
<event> Joined New York Psychoanalytic Society, New York,
N.Y.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>
<event>Published “The Preoedipal Phase of the Libido
Development,”
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Psychoanalytic Quarterly</part>
</title> (9:293-319)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946, Jan. 24</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Marie Paneth was born in Austria on August 15, 1895. She studied art
with Franz Čižek whose theories on art education for children influenced her
later work. Paneth was the daughter-in-law of Joseph Paneth, a friend of
Sigmund Freud. She met Freud in 1920 shortly before moving to the Dutch East
Indies with her husband. Paneth later moved to the United States, living and
working in New York City where she exhibited with the Society of Independent
Artists in 1939. She spent most of the war years in England where she worked as
an art instructor with children traumatized by the bombing of London. After the
war, she continued to explore the therapeutic uses of art among children who
had survived German concentration camps. Paneth returned to New York in the
early 1950s. She moved to France in the late 1960s and died in London in
November 1986.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Otto Fleischmann was born January 24,1896, in Mór, Hungary. Although originally a juris
doctor, he studied philosophy with Moritz Schlick at the University of Vienna and in
1938 became a Freudian pschoanalyst under the mentorship of August Aichhorn. Fleischmann
was associated with many psychoanalysts including Anna Freud. After the German Nazi
takeover of Austria, Fleischmann went to Budapest, Hungary. In 1944, with the German
occupation of Hungary, he received protection from the Swedish Foreign Ministry through
diplomatic cover provided by Raoul Wallenberg. Fleischmann subsequently worked with
Wallenberg in his efforts to save Jews in Hungary, 1944-1945. In 1948, he returned to
Vienna from Budapest to help Aichhorn revive the Vienna Psychoanalytic Society (WPV)
which had been repressed under Nazi rule. He served as Secretary and Vice President of
the WPV until his emigration to the United States to join the faculty of the Menninger
Clinic in Topeka, Kansas, in 1949. He died January 8, 1963, in New York City.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist>
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Charles Julius Allen (1840-1915) graduated from the United States
Military Academy in 1864. He served in the army corps of engineers until 1904,
including in the Military Division of West Mississippi and Department of
Louisiana, 1864-1866, during the Civil War period. Allen was in charge of
defenses of Washington, D.C., during the Spanish-American War. He was promoted
to brigadier-general in 1904 and retired at his request that same year. He died
in 1915.</p>
<p>Grace Elizabeth Allen, his daughter (1886-1976), was educated at
Columbia Hospital in Washington, D.C., the New York School of Social Work, and
Columbia University. She engaged in welfare work in North Carolina and for the
United States government and served on behalf of the American Red Cross.</p>
</bioghist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>
<emph render="bold">Sunday, Billy</emph>
</p>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1862, Nov. 19</datesingle>
<event>Born near Ames, Iowa</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1872</datesingle>
<event>Sent by impoverished mother to orphanage in Glenwood,
Iowa</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1880</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Marshalltown, Iowa</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1883</datesingle>
<event>Signed to play baseball by the Chicago White Stockings
baseball club</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1886</fromdate>
<todate>1887</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Converted to Christianity and began attending the Presbyterian
Church</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1888</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Sold to the Pittsburgh Alleghenys baseball club</event>
<event>Married Helen Amelia Thompson</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1890</fromdate>
<todate>1891</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Played for the Philadelphia Phillies before retiring from
baseball</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1891</datesingle>
<event>Became assistant secretary of the Chicago, Ill., YMCA</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1896</fromdate>
<todate>1935</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Conducted Christian evangelistic meetings throughout the
country; credited with giving more than twenty thousand sermons to audiences
totaling more than one hundred million people</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1903</datesingle>
<event>Ordained by the Presbyterian Church</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1935, Nov. 6</datesingle>
<event>Died, Chicago, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>

<chronitem>

<event>Born, Boston, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>

<daterange>
<fromdate>1833</fromdate>

</title>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>William Shippen Jr.</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1736, Oct. 21 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Philadelphia, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1750</datesingle>
<event>Entered the College of New Jersey, Princeton, N.J. (later reorganized as
the Princeton University)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1754</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, College of New Jersey</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1758</datesingle>
<event>Traveled to Europe to study medicine</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1760</datesingle>
<event>Married Alice Lee (died 1801)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1761</datesingle>
<event>M.D., University of Edinburgh, Scotland</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1762</datesingle>
<event>Returned to Philadelphia, entered medical practice there with his father,
and began teaching anatomy and midwifery</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1765</datesingle>
<event>Began teaching surgery and anatomy at the newly organized medical school of
the College of Philadelphia (later reorganized as the University of
Pennsylvania). </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1777</datesingle>
<event>Appointed director of Continental Army hospitals during the Revolutionary
War</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1780</datesingle>
<event>Court-martialed for speculating in hospital supplies, acquitted</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1781</datesingle>
<event>Resigned from his directorship of the Continental Army hospitals</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1791</datesingle>
<event>Joined the staff of the Pennsylvania Hospital; remained until 1802</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1805</datesingle>
<event>Became president, College of Physicians of Philadelphia</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1808, July 11</datesingle>
<event>Died, Philadelphia, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Organizational History</head>
<p>In 1972, Terri P. Tepper, cofounder and director of the Center for a Woman’s Own Name,
petitioned the 19th Judicial Circuit Court of Illinois to change her surname and to
recognize Ms. as a legal title. The petition was granted, making Tepper the first woman
in Illinois to regain her chosen name after marriage and marking the first time the
State of Illinois recognized Ms. as a legally designated title. The material in this
collection relates to Tepper's name change petition and the creation of the Center for a
Woman’s Own Name and contains only passing references to the legal recognition of Ms. </p>
<p>The Center for a Woman’s Own Name began informally in 1973 when Tepper placed an
advertisement in <emph render="italic">Ms.</emph> magazine seeking information on state
law and policies relating to women’s names. The Center was incorporated later that year,
with Tepper as director and president; Priscilla Ruth MacDougall as director, vice
president, and legal consultant; and Diana Altman as director. The Center developed into
a clearinghouse for information concerning state laws, lawsuits, and various legal and
social issues relating to women’s efforts to retain their chosen name after marriage.
The Center did not advocate that women retain their maiden names after marriage;
instead, the Center maintained that women had a right to determine their legal name
irrespective of their marital status.</p>
<p>Through a network of volunteers, the Center tracked legal opinions and on-going lawsuits
on a state-by-state basis. With correspondence from the general public, prominent
individuals, national organizations, and government officials, the collection’s strength
lies in its ability to document the evolving societal attitudes and legal opinions
around the name issue as well as individual and institutional responses to women
maintaining their own names after marriage.</p>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>
<emph render="bold">Terri P. Tepper</emph>
</p>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942, May 29</datesingle>
<event>Born Denver, Colo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1964</datesingle>
<event>B.S., education, Boston University, Boston, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1964, Aug. 23</datesingle>
<event>Married Lawrence Jay Weiner</event>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1860, May 25</datesingle>
<event>Born, Easton, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1880</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, Lafayette College, Easton, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1882</datesingle>
<event>Studied at Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1883</datesingle>
<event>M.A., Lafayette College, Easton, Pa. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1883</fromdate>
<todate>1886</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Research assistant to Wilhelm Wundt</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1886</datesingle>
<event>Ph.D., University of Leipzig, Leipzig, Germany</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1886</fromdate>
<todate>1888</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Fellow, St. John's College, Cambridge University, Cambridge, England, and
lectured at Cambridge</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>

<bioghist>
<head>George Gamow </head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1904, Mar. 4</datesingle>
<event>Born Georgii Antonovic Gamov, Odessa, Russia</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1928</datesingle>
<event>Ph.D., physical science, University of Leningrad, Leningrad,
USSR</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1928</fromdate>
<todate>1929</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Institute of Theoretical Physics, Copenhagen,
Denmark</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1929</fromdate>
<todate>1930</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Rockefeller fellow, Cambridge University, Cambridge,
England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1931</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Married Lyubov Rho Vokhminzeva (divorced 1956)</event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Constitution of Atomic Nuclei and
Radioactivity</part>
</title>. Oxford: Clarendon Press</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1931</fromdate>
<todate>1933</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Professor, University of Leningrad, Leningrad, USSR</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1933</fromdate>
<todate>1934</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Lecturer, Paris, France, London, England, and University of
Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1934</fromdate>
<todate>1956</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Professor of physics, George Washington University,
Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1935</datesingle>
<event>Collaborated with Edward Teller on the theory of beta-decay,
and formulated the so-called "Gamow-Teller Selection Rule for Beta
Emission"</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1939</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Proposed neutrino theory of supernovae</event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Mr. Tompkins in Wonderland</part>
</title>. Cambridge: Cambridge
University Press</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Became naturalized American citizen</event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Birth and Death of the Sun</part>
</title>. New York: Viking
Press</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1941</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Biography of the Earth; Its Past, Present, and
Future</part>
</title>. New York: Viking Press </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942</datesingle>
<event>Shell model of red giant stars</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1947</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>One, Two, Three...Infinity</part>
</title>. New York: Viking
Press</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1948</datesingle>
<event>Theory of the origin of chemical elements</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1952</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>The Creation of the Universe</part>
</title>. New York: Viking
Press</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1956</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Kalinga Prize by Unesco for popularization of
science</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1956</fromdate>
<todate>1968</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Professor of physics, University of Colorado, Boulder,
Colo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1958</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Matter, Earth, and Sky</part>
</title>. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.:
Prentice-Hall</event>
<event>Married Barbara Merrihew Perkins</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1961</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Biography of Physics</part>
</title>. New York: Harper</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1968, Aug. 20</datesingle>
<event>Died, Boulder, Colo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1970</datesingle>
<event>Posthumous publication
<title localtype="simple">
<part> My World Line</part>
</title>. New York: Viking Press</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<head>Barbara Gamow</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1905, May 22</datesingle>
<event>Born Barbara Merrihew Perkins, San Francisco, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1938</datesingle>
<event>Married J. R. de la Torre Bueno (divorced circa
1943)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1950</fromdate>
<todate>1958</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Employed by Cambridge University Press</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1958</datesingle>
<event>Married George Gamow</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1976</datesingle>
<event>Died</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Poet Juan Ramón Jiménez was born in 1881 in Moguer, Spain. He
published his first book of poetry in 1900 with the help of Rubén Darío, the
leader of the <emph render="italic">modernista</emph> poetry movement in Spain
and influential mentor of Jiménez. During the Spanish Civil War, Jiménez
moved first to Cuba and then to Puerto Rico where he spent most of the rest of
his life. He was the recipient of the 1956 Nobel Prize in Literature. Jiménez
died in San Juan, Puerto Rico in 1958.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>

<event>Died, Washington, D.C.</event>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Eugenio María de Hostos </head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1839, Jan. 11</datesingle>
<event>Born, Mayagüez, Puerto Rico</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1852</datesingle>
<event>Studied at the Institute of Bilbao and the University of
Madrid, Madrid, Spain</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1860</datesingle>
<event>J.D., Central University of Madrid Law School, Madrid,
Spain</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1860</fromdate>
<todate>1869</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Active in Spanish politics, advocating the independence of
Puerto Rico and Cuba</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1863</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part> La peregrinacion de Bayoán</part>
</title>. Madrid: Imprenta del
Comercio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1869</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Banished from Spain after denouncing Emelio Castelar,
Spain’s first republican president, for refusing to grant independence to
Puerto Rico and Cuba</event>
<event>Emigrated to the United States and became editor of La
revolución, newspaper of the Cuban Revolutionary Junta of pro-independence
Cuban exiles in New York City</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1870</datesingle>
<event>Toured South America to generate support for the Puerto
Rican and Cuban independence movements and to promote education reforms</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1871?</fromdate>
<todate>1874?</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Teacher, University of Chile, Santiago, Chile</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1872</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Hamlet: ensayo crítico</part>
</title>. Santiago: Imprenta de
Ferrocarril</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1875</datesingle>
<event>Editor,
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Las tres Antillas</part>
</title>, Dominican Republic</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1877</datesingle>
<event>Married Belinda Otilia de Ayala, daughter of a Cuban
emigré, in Venezuela</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1880</fromdate>
<todate>1888</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Inspector general of public instruction, Dominican
Republic</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1887</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Lecciones de derecho constitucional</part>
</title>. Santo
Domingo: Cuna de América</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1888</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Moral social</part>
</title>. Santo Domingo: Imprenta de Garcia
Hermanos</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1888</fromdate>
<todate>1890</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Headmaster, Miguel Luis Amunátequi secondary school,
Chile</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1890</fromdate>
<todate>1898</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Professor, University of Chile, Santiago, Chile</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1895</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Geografía evolutiva</part>
</title>. Santiago de Chile: R.
Miranda</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1898</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Returned to Puerto Rico to work for Puerto Rican and Cuban
independence</event>
<event>Formed the League of Puerto Rican Patriots</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1899</datesingle>
<event>Led commission to President William McKinley to ask for
Puerto Rican freedom</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1903, Aug. 11</datesingle>
<event>Died, Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<todate>1916</todate>

<todate>1919</todate>
</daterange>

Columbia, Chiriqui, Panama Republic, and Guatemala. Commanding officer, 1918
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1918</fromdate>
<todate>1919</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Promoted to major, then to lieutenant colonel and made
battalion commander</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1919</datesingle>
<event>Returned to Puerto Rico with the Porto Rico Regiment of
Infantry</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1924</datesingle>
<event>Reserve officer, U.S. Army</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1935</datesingle>
<event>Purchased as family home the castle of Sotomayor,
Pontevedra, Spain</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>
<event>Published with Adolfo de Hostos
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Indice hemero-bibliográfico de Eugenio María de
Hostos</part>
</title>. Havana: Cultural, s.a.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1952</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Antología. Prólogo por Pedro Henríquez Ureña;
selección, arreglo y apéndice por Eugenio Carlos de Hostos </part>
</title>(editor).
Madrid: Litografía y Encuadernación</event>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Hostos, hispanoamericanista: colección de ensayos
acerca de Eugenio María de Hostos</part>
</title> (editor). Madrid: Litografía y
Encuadernación</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1953</datesingle>
<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Eugenio María de Hostos, Promoter of
Panamericanism</part>
</title>. Madrid: Litografía y Encuadernación</event>

<event>Published
<title localtype="simple">
<part>España y América. Prólogo por Francisco Elías de
Tejada. Recopilación y arreglo por Eugenio Carlos de Hostos</part>
</title> (editor).
Paris: Ediciones Literarias y Artísticas</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1959, May 27</datesingle>
<event>Died, Madrid, Spain</event>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1859, Mar. 26</datesingle>
<event>Born, Worcestershire, England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1870</fromdate>
<todate>1877</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended Bromsgrove School, Worcestershire, England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1877</fromdate>
<todate>1881</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended St. John’s College, Oxford, England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1882</fromdate>
<todate>1892</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Higher division clerk, Patent Office, London, England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1892</datesingle>

<todate>1814</todate>

<event>Took charge of <title localtype="simple">
<part>Argus of Western America</part>

<event>Changed political support from Henry Clay to Andrew Jackson</event>
<event>Married Jane Kyle.</event>

<daterange>
<fromdate>1829</fromdate>
<todate>1837</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Member of President Andrew Jackson’s inner circle of advisors, known
informally as the “Kitchen Cabinet”</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>circa 1830s</datesingle>
<event>Edited and wrote for the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Globe</part>
</title>, a Jacksonian and Democratic organ published in Washington, D.C., and
founded <title localtype="simple">
<part>Kendall’s Expositor</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>

<daterange>
<fromdate>1835</fromdate>
<todate>1840</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Postmaster general</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1843</datesingle>
<event>Became agent for collection of claims against the government, including on
behalf of Cherokee Indians </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1845</datesingle>
<event>Entered business partnership with Samuel Finley Breese Morse </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1857</datesingle>
<event>Helped found Columbia Institution for the Deaf and Dumb, which later became
Gallaudet University, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1862</datesingle>
<event>Helped found Calvary Baptist Church, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1869, Nov. 12</datesingle>
<event>Died, Washington, D.C.</event>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Amory Austin was born to Ivers James Austin and Elizabeth Turner Amory
Austin on July 24, 1849, in Boston, Massachusetts. He received a bachelor's
degree from Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, in 1871 and an S. B.
from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, also in Cambridge, in 1873. He
worked in analytical chemistry. In 1890, Austin was appointed expert compiler
in the Statistical Division of the Department of Agriculture in Washington,
D.C. He died on January 4, 1920, in Newport, Rhode Island.</p>
</bioghist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1832</datesingle>
<event>Born, Elkton, Ky.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1851</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, Jefferson College, Washington, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1853</datesingle>
<event>Admitted to Kentucky bar after studying law with his father,
Francis Bristow, congressman from Kentucky.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1861</fromdate>
<todate>1865</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Officer in Kentucky infantry and Kentucky calvary; wounded at
the Battle of Shiloh (1863) and assisted in the capture of John Hunt Morgan
during his raid through Indiana and Ohio (July 1863)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1863</fromdate>
<todate>1865</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Kentucky state senator</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1865</fromdate>
<todate>1866</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Assistant United States attorney</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1866</fromdate>
<todate>1870</todate>
</daterange>
<event>United States district attorney for Louisville, Ky.,
district</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1870</fromdate>
<todate>1872</todate>
</daterange>
<event>First solicitor general of the United States</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1874</fromdate>
<todate>1876</todate>
</daterange>
<chronitemset>
<event>Secretary of the treasury</event>
<event>Reorganized Treasury Department and successfully prosecuted
the ?Whiskey Ring? accused of defrauding the federal government of tax
revenue</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1876</datesingle>
<event>Candidate for Republican Party nomination for
president</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1878</datesingle>
<event>Began law practice in New York</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1896, June 22</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Katherine Garrison Chapin was born in Waterford, Connecticut, on
September 4, 1890, and died in Pennsylvania on December 30, 1977. She was
educated at Columbia University and beginning in the 1920s became published as
a poet in such publications as <title localtype="simple">
<part>Harper's</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Scribner's</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Saturday Review</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>North American Review</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Poetry</part>
</title>, and the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Ladies' Home Journal</part>
</title>. Other of her works were set to music and performed by leading
orchestras. In 1918 she married Francis Biddle, later attorney general in the
administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt during World War II.</p>
</bioghist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1812, Mar. 19</datesingle>
<event>Born, Monroe, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1833</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Moved to Chicago, Ill.</event>
<event>Established first law office in Chicago, Ill.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1834</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Member and secretary of the first Illinois political
convention held in Ottawa, Ill.</event>
<event>Elected justice of the peace, Ottawa, Ill.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1835</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Married Laura Sherill</event>
<event>Admitted to the Illinois bar</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1837</datesingle>
<event>Elected as an alderman in Chicago, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1842</fromdate>
<todate>1864</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Associate justice of the Illinois Supreme Court and served as
chief justice in 1855 and again from 1857 to 1864</event>
</chronitem>

<daterange>
<fromdate>1849</fromdate>
<todate>1867</todate>
</daterange>

Co.</event>

Houghton</event>

<head>Administrative History</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1959</datesingle>
<event>Like-minded Democrats in the House of Representative establish the Democratic
Study Group (DSG) to mobilize and coordinate efforts to enact progressive programs
William G. Phillips appointed staff director</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1960</fromdate>
<todate>1968</todate>
</daterange>
<event>DSG plays leadership role in passing Kennedy-Johnson legislative
agenda</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1968</datesingle>
<event>Richard Conlon appointed executive director, serving twenty years until his
death in a boating accident</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1970</fromdate>
<todate>1990</todate>
</daterange>
<event>DSG active in reforming parliamentary rules of the United States House of
Representatives</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1988</datesingle>
<event>Scott Lilly appointed executive director</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1995</datesingle>
<event>DSG dissolved under Republican majority reform rules abolishing the
organization as a congressionally funded entity</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1865, June 29</datesingle>
<event>Born, Jasper Township, near Fairfield, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1885</fromdate>
<todate>1887</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kans.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1887</datesingle>
<event>Admitted to the Kansas bar</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1890</datesingle>
<event>Settled in Boise, Idaho; practiced law</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1895</datesingle>
<event>Married Mary McConnell</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1896</datesingle>
<event>Ran for the House of Representatives on the Silver-Republican ticket</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1903</datesingle>
<event>Ran for the United States Senate</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1907</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Elected to the United States Senate from Idaho</event>
<event>Prosecutor in the trial of William Dudley (“Big Bill”) Haywood, socialist
labor leader charged with murder</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1919</fromdate>
<todate>1920</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Opposed entry of the United States into the League of Nations</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1923</datesingle>
<event>Introduced first of several Senate resolutions to outlaw war</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1924</datesingle>
<event>Succeeded Henry Cabot Lodge as chairman, Senate Committee on Foreign
Relations</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1928</fromdate>
<todate>1929</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Led fight in Senate for Kellogg-Briand peace pact</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1936</datesingle>
<event>Candidate, Republican Party nomination for president</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Joseph Brodsky was born in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg), Soviet
Union, on May 24, 1940. He left school in 1955, held a variety of jobs, and
began a program of self-education during which he taught himself Polish and
English. By the late 1950s, Brodsky had started writing poetry and producing
literary translations that were published in samizdat editions and in 1960 met
the Russian poet Anna Akhmatova, who became Brodsky's mentor and advocate. In
1964, Brodsky was charged and convicted as a "social parasite" in a Soviet
court and sentenced to five years in a labor camp in Siberia. Following
protests by Akhmatova, Jean Paul-Sartre, and others, Brodsky's sentence was
reduced, and in 1972, he was forced into exile from the USSR.</p>
<p>After his exile, Brodsky emigrated to the United States and in 1977
became an American citizen. In addition to teaching positions at Columbia
University, New York, N.Y., and Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, Mass.,
where he taught for fifteen years, Brodsky also served as a visiting professor
at several other colleges and universities. In 1986 his collection of essays
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Less Than One</part>
</title> was awarded the National Book Critics Award
for Criticism, and in 1987, he received the Nobel Prize for Literature. In
1990, Brodsky married Maria Sozzani and was appointed Poet Laureate of the
United States, 1991-1992. Brodsky died on January 28, 1996, New York, N.Y.</p>
<p>Celebrated as one of the great Russian poets of his generation,
Brodsky authored nine volumes of poetry, and several collections of essays,
including
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Elegy for John Donne and Other Poems</part>
</title> (1967),
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Selected Poems</part>
</title> (1973),
<title localtype="simple">
<part>A Part of Speech </part>
</title>(1980),
<title localtype="simple">
<part>To Urania</part>
</title> (1988),
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Watermark</part>
</title> (1992), and
<title localtype="simple">
<part>On Grief and Reason</part>
</title> (1995), as well as the play
<title localtype="simple">
<part>Marbles</part>
</title> (1989).</p>
</bioghist>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Jeannette Thurber Connor, born 1872, became interested in researching
the early history of Florida after her marriage to Washington Everett Connor in
1913. Following her investigation into the background of a Spanish mission on
her husband's Florida estate, Connor began her research into the early Spanish
settlements and missions of Florida. She accumulated transcripts and
photocopies of original letters, reports, and other documents of Spanish
officials of Florida from 1570 to the beginning of the eigthteenth century that
had been preserved in Spanish repositories, especially the Archivo General de
Indias, Seville, Spain. Together with John B. Stetson (1884-1952), Connor
founded the Florida State Historical Society in 1921 and began a publication
project of Florida historical studies supported by the society. Among the
volumes Connor translated and edited for the series were <title localtype="simple">
<part>Pedro Menéndez de Avilés: Memorial by Gonzalo Solis de
Merás</part>
</title> (De Land, Fla.: Florida State Historial Society, 1923); <title localtype="simple">
<part>Colonial Records of Spanish Florida,</part>
</title> 2 vols. (De Land, Fla.: Florida State Historial Society, 1925 and
1930); and <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Whole and True Discouerye of Terra Florida </part>
</title>(De Land, Fla.: Florida State Historial Society, 1927). Connor died on
June 9, 1927 in New York, N.Y. Upon Connor's death and following financial
losses suffered by Stetson in 1929, the Florida State Historical Society was
discontinued and its publishing program terminated.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>
<emph render="bold">Rebekah Crawford</emph>
</p>
<chronlist>

<daterange>
<fromdate>1913</fromdate>
<todate>1920</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Relief worker, including during World War I</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1916</fromdate>
<todate>1918</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Raised funds for artificial limbs for 150 indigent Italian
soldiers</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Received Gold Medal from Italian Red Cross for Italian relief
efforts</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1921</datesingle>
<event>Received Distinguished Service Medal of the Order of the Crown
of Italy for Italian and Duryea relief work </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1934, Jan. 25</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>

<head>P. Phillips</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1807, Dec. 13</datesingle>
<event>Born, Charleston, S.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1828</datesingle>
<event>Admitted to bar</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1832</datesingle>
<event>Delegate to South Carolina State Constitutional Convention
(nullification)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1833</fromdate>
<todate>1835</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Member, South Carolina house of representatives</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1836</datesingle>
<event>Married Eugenia Yates Levy (died 1913)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1836</fromdate>
<todate>1853</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Practiced law in Mobile, Ala.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1837</datesingle>
<event>President, Alabama Democratic state convention</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1844</datesingle>
<event>Member, Alabama house of representatives</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1850</datesingle>
<event>Admitted to United States Supreme Court</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1851</datesingle>
<event>Member, Alabama house of representatives</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1853</fromdate>
<todate>1855</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Member, United States House of Representatives, 33<emph render="super">rd</emph> Congress</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1856</datesingle>
<event>Began law practice in Washington, D. C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1861</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Wife, Eugenia Levy Phillips, interned for Confederate
sympathies</event>
<event>Family sent south to Crany Island via Fort Monroe as
suspected spies for Confederate States of America.</event>
<event>Began New Orleans, La., bar practice</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1862</datesingle>
<event>Wife, Eugenia Levy Phillips, confined to Ship Island as
rebel spy and finally released by Benjamin Butler as prisoner of war after
three months</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1862</fromdate>
<todate>1866</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Began law practice in La Grange, Ga., and New Orleans,
La.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1867</datesingle>
<event>Removed to Washington, D. C., and resumed United States
Supreme Court practice</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1884, Jan. 14</datesingle>
<event>Died, Washington, D. C.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Thomas Ewing (1789-1871)</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1789, Dec. 28</datesingle>
<event>Born near West Liberty, Ohio County, Va.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1792</datesingle>
<event>Moved with family to Marietta, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1798</datesingle>
<event>Moved with family to Ames Township, Athens County,
Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1809</fromdate>
<todate>1812</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Worked intermittently at the Kanawha, Va., saltworks</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1812</fromdate>
<todate>1815</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended Ohio University, Athens, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1815</fromdate>
<todate>1816</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Studied law in the office of Philemon Beecher, Lancaster,
Ohio; admitted to the bar in 1816</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1817</fromdate>
<todate>1822</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Prosecuting attorney, Fairfield County, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1820</datesingle>
<event>Married Maria Wills Boyle (died 1864)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1829</datesingle>
<event>Adopted William T. Sherman</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1830</datesingle>
<event>Elected from Ohio, United States Senate</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1841</datesingle>
<event>Appointed secretary of the treasury; resigned Sept.
11</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1849</fromdate>
<todate>1850</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Appointed to organize the Home Department (later Department
of the Interior) and served as the first secretary of the interior</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1850</datesingle>
<event>Appointed to the United States Senate to complete unexpired
term of Thomas Corwin who became secretary of the treasury</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1851</datesingle>
<event>Retired from public service, resuming his law
practice</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1851</fromdate>
<todate>1869</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Practiced law, largely before the United States Supreme
Court</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1861</datesingle>
<event>Appointed delegate to the Peace Convention, Washington,
D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1868</datesingle>
<event>Appointed secretary of war; United States Senate did not act
on nomination</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1871, Oct. 26</datesingle>
<event>Died, Lancaster, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Thomas Ewing (1829-1896)</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1829, Aug. 7</datesingle>
<event>Born, Lancaster, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1852</fromdate>
<todate>1854</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended Brown University, Providence, R.I.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1854</fromdate>
<todate>1857</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Lived in Cincinnati, Ohio; attended Cincinnati Law School;
admitted to bar in 1855</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1856</datesingle>
<event>Married Ellen Ewing Cox</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1857</fromdate>
<todate>circa 1862</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Moved to Leavenworth, Kans., where he practiced law in the
firm Ewing, Denman &amp; Company with his brother, Hugh, and brothers-in-law,
Hampton B. Denman and William T. Sherman; firm became Sherman, Ewing &amp;
McCook in 1859</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1858</datesingle>
<event>Member, Kansas Constitutional Convention</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1861</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Appointed delegate to Peace Convention, Washington,
D.C.</event>
<event>Served as first chief justice, Kansas Supreme Court;
resigned 1862</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1862</datesingle>
<event>Brevetted major-general, United States Army; resigned
1865</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1865</datesingle>
<event>Defended Samuel Arnold, Edward Spangler, and Samuel Mudd on
charges of conspiracy to assassinate Abraham Lincoln</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1865</fromdate>
<todate>1870</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Practiced law with Ewing &amp; Browning, Washington,
D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1870</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Lancaster, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1877</fromdate>
<todate>1881</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Elected from Ohio, United States House of
Representatives</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1882</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Yonkers, New York</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1882</fromdate>
<todate>1896</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Practiced law, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1896, Jan. 21</datesingle>
<event>Died New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<todate>circa 1854</todate>

</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1856</fromdate>
<todate>1858</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended University of Virginia, Charlottesville,
Va.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1860</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Bachelor of laws, Cincinnati College, Cincinnati,
Ohio</event>
<event>Admitted to the bar, St. Louis, Mo.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1861</datesingle>
<event>Entered United States Army with rank of captain</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1863</fromdate>
<todate>1867</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Served under his brother-in-law, William T. Sherman, and was
part of the "March to the Sea"</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1865</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Brevetted colonel</event>
<event>Promoted to brigadier-general in charge of volunteers;
resigned in 1867</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1867</fromdate>
<todate>1883</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Practiced law, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1869</datesingle>
<event>Admitted to bar of the United States Supreme Court</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1870</datesingle>
<event>Married Virginia Larwill Miller (died 1937)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1874</fromdate>
<todate>1883</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Served as Catholic commissioner of Indian missions; became
Bureau of Catholic Indian Missions in 1874</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1883, June 20</datesingle>
<event>Died, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<listhead>

<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1826, Oct. 31</datesingle>
<event>Born, Lancaster, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1848</datesingle>
<event>Entered United States Military Academy, West Point, N.Y.;
resigned before graduation</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1854</fromdate>
<todate>1856</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Admitted to the bar and practiced law, St. Louis,
Mo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1857</fromdate>
<todate>1861</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Moved to Leavenworth, Kans., where he practiced law in the
firm Ewing, Denman &amp; Company with his brother, Thomas, and brothers-in-law,
Hampton B. Denman and William T. Sherman; firm became Sherman, Ewing &amp;
McCook in 1859; speculated in lands, roads, and government housing</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1858</datesingle>
<event>Married Henrietta Young (died 1927)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1861</datesingle>
<event>Entered United States Army with rank of major</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1862</datesingle>
<event>Promoted to brigadier-general of volunteers</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1865</datesingle>
<event>Brevetted major-general of volunteers; resigned in
1866</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1866</fromdate>
<todate>1870</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Served as minister to Holland</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1870</fromdate>
<todate>circa 1875</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Practiced law, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>circa 1875</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Lancaster, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1905, June 30</datesingle>
<event>Died near Lancaster, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>

<head>Thomas Ewing (1789-1871)</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1789, Dec. 28</datesingle>
<event>Born near West Liberty, Ohio County, Va.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1792</datesingle>
<event>Moved with family to Marietta, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1798</datesingle>
<event>Moved with family to Ames Township, Athens County,
Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1809</fromdate>
<todate>1812</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Worked intermittently at the Kanawha, Va., saltworks</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1812</fromdate>
<todate>1815</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended Ohio University, Athens, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1815</fromdate>
<todate>1816</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Studied law in the office of Philemon Beecher, Lancaster,
Ohio; admitted to the bar in 1816</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1817</fromdate>
<todate>1822</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Prosecuting attorney, Fairfield County, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1820</datesingle>
<event>Married Maria Wills Boyle (died 1864)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1829</datesingle>
<event>Adopted William T. Sherman</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1830</datesingle>
<event>Elected from Ohio, United States Senate</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1841</datesingle>
<event>Appointed secretary of the treasury; resigned Sept.
11</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1849</fromdate>
<todate>1850</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Appointed to organize the Home Department (later Department
of the Interior) and served as the first secretary of the interior</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1850</datesingle>
<event>Appointed to the United States Senate to complete unexpired
term of Thomas Corwin who became secretary of the treasury</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1851</datesingle>
<event>Retired from public service, resuming his law
practice</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1851</fromdate>
<todate>1869</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Practiced law, largely before the United States Supreme
Court</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1861</datesingle>
<event>Appointed delegate to the Peace Convention, Washington,
D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1868</datesingle>
<event>Appointed secretary of war; United States Senate did not act
on nomination</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1871, Oct. 26</datesingle>
<event>Died, Lancaster, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Oliver Freud</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1891, Feb. 19 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Vienna, Austria, son of Sigmund and Martha Bernays
Freud</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>circa 1915 </datesingle>
<event>Graduated with degree in civil engineering from Vienna
Technical Institute, Vienna, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1916</fromdate>
<todate>1918</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Served in Austrian army, World War I</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920s </datesingle>
<event>Engineer, various firms, Berlin, Germany</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1923 </datesingle>
<event>Married Henny Fuchs</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1933</fromdate>
<todate>1943</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Worked as a commercial photographer in France</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1943 </datesingle>
<event>Immigrated to United States</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1943</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Taught mathematics, United States Army specialized training
program</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1945</fromdate>
<todate>1958</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Engineer, Budd Co., Philadelphia, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1969, Jan. 24 </datesingle>
<event>Died, Williamstown, Mass. </event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Henny Fuchs Freud</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1892, Nov. 2 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Berlin, Germany</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920s </datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Graduated from Charlotten Lyceum, Berlin, Germany</event>
<event>Studied art under Lovis Corinth and graduated from State
Academy of Fine Arts, Weimar, Germany</event>
<event>Studied at academies of fine arts in Berlin and
Dusseldorf, Germany</event>
<event>Exhibited paintings at various shows in Germany and
France</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1923 </datesingle>
<event>Married Oliver Freud</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1924 </datesingle>
<event>Birth of daughter, Eva Mathilde Freud (died in France,
1944)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1933</fromdate>
<todate>1943</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Lived in France</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1943</datesingle>
<event> Immigrated to the United States</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1945</fromdate>
<todate>circa 1965</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Exhibited artwork at various shows in the United
States</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1971, Apr. 30 </datesingle>
<event>Died, Williamstown, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Oliver Freud</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1891, Feb. 19 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Vienna, Austria, son of Sigmund and Martha Bernays
Freud</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>circa 1915 </datesingle>
<event>Graduated with degree in civil engineering from Vienna
Technical Institute, Vienna, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1916</fromdate>
<todate>1918</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Served in Austrian army, World War I</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920s </datesingle>
<event>Engineer, various firms, Berlin, Germany</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1923 </datesingle>
<event>Married Henny Fuchs</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1933</fromdate>
<todate>1943</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Worked as a commercial photographer in France</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1943 </datesingle>
<event>Immigrated to United States</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1943</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Taught mathematics, United States Army specialized training
program</event>
</chronitem>

</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>John Charles Frémont (1813-1890) first gained public attention
through his participation in and eventual leadership of scientific and mapping
expeditions in the American West (1838, 1841, 1842, 1843, and 1845). In 1841 he
married Jessie Ann Benton (1824-1902), the daughter of Senator Thomas Hart
Benton of Missouri, who was an advocate of United States expansion into the
West and a political supporter of his son-in-law's expeditions, which received
Congressional backing. Jessie Benton Frémont assisted in the writing of her
husband's 1844 expedition report, which enjoyed popularity with the general
public, and with his subsequent writings. During his final expedition, Frémont
became involved in California's uprising against Mexico. He was appointed
military governor of California, but later was arrested and court-martialed in
Washington, D.C., in 1847-1848 for disobedience. His penalty was set aside by
President James K. Polk and he and Jessie moved to California in 1849. They
became wealthy after the discovery of gold on their Las Mariposas land grant.
In 1850, Frémont was elected senator from the new state of California and
served briefly in that office. He ran as the first presidential candidate of
the Republican party in 1856 on a free-soil anti-slavery platform. He served as
a Union general in the Department of the West during the Civil War. Frémont
was governor of the Arizona terrritory, 1878-1883. He died in New York City in
1890. The Frémonts suffered economic reversals and in later years were
supported primarily through Jessie Benton Frémont's writings. During the 1870s
through the 1890s she authored books, stories, and many articles that appeared
in leading magazines. She died in Los Angeles, California, in 1902.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Robert Emmet Sherwood was born April 4, 1896, in New Rochelle, N.Y.
Sherwood was a playwright, editor, screen writer, and cofounder of the
Playwrights’ Company, a producing company. He wrote speeches for President
Franklin D. Roosevelt during World War II and from 1941 to 1944 served as head
of the overseas branch of the Office of War Information. Sherwood’s book <title localtype="simple">
<part>Roosevelt and Hopkins </part>
</title>(1948) won the Pulitzer Prize, as did several plays, including <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Road to Rome</part>
</title> (1927) and <title localtype="simple">
<part>Abe Lincoln in Illinois</part>
</title> (1938). His original screenplay, <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Best Years of Our Lives</part>
</title>, won the Academy Award in 1946. Sherwood died in New York, November
14, 1955.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1896, Dec. 14</datesingle>
<event>Born, Alameda, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1916</datesingle>
<event>Entered University of California, Berkeley, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1917</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Flying cadet, United States Army Signal Corps</event>
<event>Married Josephine Daniels (died 1988)</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1918</datesingle>
<event>Completed flight training and commissioned second lieutenant</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Regular commission and promoted to first lieutenant</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1922</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Bachelor of arts, University of California, Berkeley, Calif.</event>
<event>First air crossing of the United States under twenty-four hours</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1924</datesingle>
<event>Masters of science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1925</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Doctorate in aeronautical engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston, Mass.</event>
<event>Won Schneider Cup Race</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1927</datesingle>
<event>First flier to perform outside loop</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1930</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Resigned regular army commission</event>
<event>Awarded Harmon Trophy</event>
<event>Manager, Aviation Division, Shell Oil Co.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1931</datesingle>
<event>Won Bendix Trophy Race from Burbank, Calif. to Cleveland, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1932</datesingle>
<event>Won Thompson Trophy, Cleveland, Ohio
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>President of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences</event>
<event>Returned to active duty, Army Air Corps</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Led sixteen B-25 bombers off deck of aircraft carrier in bombing raid over Japan</event>
<event>Promoted to brigadier general</event>
<event>Promoted to major general</event>
<event>Awarded Congressional Medal of Honor</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1943</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<chronitemset>
<event>Commanded Twelfth Air Force in North Africa</event>
<event>Commanded Fifteenth Air Force in Mediterranean theater</event>
<event>Commanded Eighth Air Force in Europe and the Pacific</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946</datesingle>
<event>Inactive reserve status</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1946</fromdate>
<todate>1967</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Vice president, Shell Oil Co.; later a director</event>
</chronitem>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Organizational History</head>
<p>The New York Society for the Suppression of Vice was founded in 1873
by Anthony Comstock and his supporters as a committee within the Young Men’s
Christian Association of the City of New York to supervise public morality in
the state, bring offenders to justice, and advocate for stricter legislation
against immoral conduct. Chartered by the state legislature, it became
prominent as a monitor and censor of literary works and popular literature.
Comstock, who became its secretary, was succeeded after his death in 1915 by
John S. Summer. The society was dissolved after Summer’s death in 1950.</p>
</bioghist>

<todate>1922</todate>

<part>Electrical World</part>

<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1739, Mar. 30</datesingle>
<event> Born near New Brunswick, N.J. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1784 </datesingle>
<event>Appointed member of the committee to receive subscription for
the stock in the Bank of New York </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1785</datesingle>
<event> Elected a director of the Bank of New York </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1788</datesingle>
<event> Elected on the Federalist slate to the New York state
convention that met at Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and ratified the United States
Constitution</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle> 1793</datesingle>
<event> Gave support to the Society for Establishing Useful
Manufactures, Paterson, N.J.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle> 1796 </datesingle>
<event>Became a part proprietor of a large tract of land in Jefferson
and Lewis counties, New York, beginning his career as a land speculator
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1810 </datesingle>
<event>Built a hotel and a cotton factory, Ballston, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1814 </datesingle>
<event>Joined the New York Hussars to defend New York, N.Y., against
the British </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1826, Nov. 15 </datesingle>
<event>Died, New York</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1772, Jan. 14</datesingle>
<event> Born, Dutchess County, N.Y. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1780 </datesingle>
<event>Moved to Pittsburgh, Pa. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1790 </datesingle>
<event>Participated in Josiah Harmar's campaign against the Shawnee Tribe of Native
Americans and other expeditions </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1792</fromdate>
<todate>1793</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Worked as a salt-boiler near Maysville, Ky. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1793</datesingle>
<event> Joined a party surveying under Nathaniel Massie from the Scioto River Valley
to the area around Chillicothe, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1893</fromdate>
<todate>1895</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Observed the movement of Native Americans as a ranger </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1795</datesingle>
<event> Rejoined Nathaniel Massie and learned surveying </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1796 </datesingle>
<event>Married Nancy McDonald and settled near Chillicothe, Ohio </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1804 </datesingle>
<event>Elected to lower house, Ohio legislature </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1805</fromdate>
<todate>1814</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Member, Ohio state senate, speaker for the 1809-1810 session </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1806 </datesingle>
<event>Elected a colonel in the Ohio militia </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1808 </datesingle>
<event>Promoted to major-general </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1812 </datesingle>
<event>Marched with Ohio militia for Detroit and later was elected colonel of one of
the three militia regiments under the command of William Hull </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1813</datesingle>
<event> Brigadier general, Ohio Volunteers in defense of Fort Meigs </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1814 </datesingle>
<event>Commanded troops at Sacketts Harbor on Lake Ontario and later appointed
commander of the army in the Northwest </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1815</fromdate>
<todate>1816</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Member, lower house, Ohio state legislature </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1816</datesingle>
<event> Member of various commissions for treaty-making with Native Americans

</chronitem>

<fromdate>1817</fromdate>
<todate>1818</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Member, lower house, Ohio state legislature </event>
</chronitem>

<fromdate>1821</fromdate>
<todate>1823</todate>
</daterange>

</chronitem>

<fromdate>1823</fromdate>
<todate>1825</todate>

<todate>1832</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Governor of Ohio </event>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1874, Jan. 1 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Boston, Mass. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1881 </datesingle>
<event>Moved to Grand Rapids, Mich.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1898 </datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>A.B., Alma College, Alma, Mich.</event>
<event>Private in “Rough Rider” regiment of Leonard Wood and Theodore
Roosevelt</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1890</datesingle>
<event> Married Annie Reid</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle> 1898</datesingle>
<event> Reporter, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Grand Rapids Herald</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1902 </datesingle>
<event>With John Adam Muehling purchased the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Lake Superior Journal</part>
</title>, Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1912 </datesingle>
<event>Sold <title localtype="simple">
<part> Lake Superior Journal</part>
</title> and started the Manchester Union and Leader. Manchester, N.H. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1917</fromdate>
<todate>1918</todate>
</daterange>
<event> Artillery officer with American Expeditionary Force in France </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1928 </datesingle>
<event>Became publisher of <title localtype="simple">
<part>Boston American</part>
</title> for William Randolph Hearst</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle> 1929 </datesingle>
<event>Appointed general manager for all Hearst newspapers</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle> 1931 </datesingle>
<event>Resigned from Hearst organization </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1932</datesingle>

</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1918, Nov. 8</datesingle>
<event>Born, Bay City, Mich.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1941</datesingle>
<event>S.B. in chemistry, University of Chicago, Chicago,
Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942</datesingle>
<event>Joined the University of Chicago’s Metallurgical Laboratory
(code name for the Manhattan Project) as a member of Charles D. Coryell's team,
Chicago, Ill. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1943</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Transferred to Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge,
Tenn.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1945</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Discovered with Jacob A. Marinsky, Promethium, the 61st
element on the periodic table</event>
<event>One of sixty-seven Oak Ridge Laboratory scientists who
signed the Oak Ridge petition calling for President Harry S. Truman to describe
and demonstrate the atomic bomb's power and give Japan the opportunity to
surrender</event>
<event>Married Ethel Long</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1946</fromdate>
<todate>1949</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Ph.D. in nuclear chemistry, Massachusetts Institute of
Technology, Cambridge, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1947</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Patent issued for Brady-Glendenin safety pipette</event>
<event>Member of radio chemistry team, Bikini Scientific Resurvey,
studying effects of atomic bomb testing on the Bikini Atoll (Marshall
Islands)</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1949</fromdate>
<todate>1985</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Senior scientist, Chemistry Division, Argonne National
Laboratory, Argonne, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1958</datesingle>
<event>Visiting scientist, Metallurgy Division, Harwell Laboratory,
Oxon, United Kingdom</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1963</datesingle>
<event>Appointed scientific secretary, United States delegation to
the International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy, Geneva
Switzerland</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1974</datesingle>
<event>American Chemical Society Award for Nuclear Applications in
Chemistry</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>2008</datesingle>
<event>Died, Nov. 22, Crystal Lake, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1874 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Olympia, Wash. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1892 </datesingle>
<event>Graduated high school, Lawrenceville, N. J.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1896 </datesingle>
