<head>Biographical Note</head>
<bioghist>
<head>Paul Field Sifton </head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1897, Oct. 17</datesingle>
<event>Born, Rockford, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1915</datesingle>
<event>Graduate, Benton Harbor, Mich., high school</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1917</fromdate>
<todate>1919</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Private, first class, Headquarters Company, 6th Field Artillery, 1st
Division, American Expeditionary Forces, invalided out with diagnosis of
pulmonary tuberculosis</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1919</fromdate>
<todate>1920</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended University of Missouri, Columbia, Mo., on federal program for
disabled veterans</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1921</datesingle>
<event>Attended London School of Economics, London, England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1922</datesingle>
<event>Married Claire E. Ginsburg</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1922</fromdate>
<todate>1923</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Reporter, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Des Moines Register</part>
</title>, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Staten Island Advance</part>
</title>, United Press syndicate, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Chicago Journal</part>
</title>, and the <title localtype="simple">
<part>New Leader</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1923</fromdate>
<todate>1931</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Assistant Sunday editor, feature writer, and reporter, <title localtype="simple">
<part>New York World</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1927</datesingle>
<event>Play, <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Belt</part>
</title>, produced by the New Playwrights' Theatre, published by Macaulay, New
York</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1929</datesingle>
<event>Veterans Administration ruled tuberculosis that his was arrested; awarded
reduced disability pension</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1930</datesingle>
<event>Play written with Claire Sifton, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Midnight</part>
</title>, produced by the Theatre Guild; Universal motion picture (1934); and
West German television play (1957)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1931</datesingle>
<event>Play written with Claire Sifton, <title localtype="simple">
<part>1931---</part>
</title>, produced by the Group Theatre and the Theatre Guild; published by
Farrar &amp; Rinehart, New York; and produced in London as <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Age of Plenty</part>
</title> (1933)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933</datesingle>
<event>Play written with Claire Sifton, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Blood on the Moon</part>
</title>, produced at the Mayan Theatre, Los Angeles, Calif; the London,
England, production was halted by the Lord Chamberlain as an unfriendly act to
a foreign country, Germany</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1933</fromdate>
<todate>1934</todate>
</daterange>
<event>On editorial staff, <title localtype="simple">
<part>New Yorker</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1934</fromdate>
<todate>1938</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Labor publications editor, assistant industrial commissioner, deputy
industrial commissioner and administrator, and executive director, Division of
Placement and Unemployment Insurance, New York State Department of
Labor</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1938</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>One-act play written with Claire Sifton, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Give All Thy Terrors to the Wind</part>
</title>, published in the <title localtype="simple">
<part>New Theatre an Film Magazine</part>
</title> (January 1938), and in the anthology, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Best Short Plays of the Social Theatre</part>
</title>, edited by William Kozlenko (New York, Random House, 1938)</event>
<event>One-act play written with Claire Sifton, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Kate Larsen</part>
</title>, published in the <title localtype="simple">
<part>One Act Play Magazine</part>
</title> (June-July 1938 issue)</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1938</fromdate>
<todate>1939</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Deputy administrator, Wages and Hours Division, U.S. Department of
Labor</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1939</datesingle>
<event>One-act play written with Claire Ginsburg Sifton, <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Doctors</part>
</title>, produced in Boston, Mass., and Baltimore, Md.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1939</fromdate>
<todate>1941</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Consumers' counsel, Bituminous Coal Administration, U.S. Department of the
Interior</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1942</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Labor and public relations director, National Farmers' Union, Washington,
D.C., office</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1944</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Director, Washington D. C., office, Union for Democratic Action [later
Americans for Democratic Action], and editor with Claire Sifton of the <title localtype="simple">
<part>U.D.A. Congressional Newsletter</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1945</fromdate>
<todate>1947</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Worked on legislative and public relations for various causes, including
Full Employment Bill (1945), protection of the Children's Bureau under
Reorganization Bill No. 2 (1946), Labor Extension Service bill, National
Council for a permanent Fair Employment Practices bill), National Consumers'
League, and others</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1948</fromdate>
<todate>1962</todate>
</daterange>
<event>National legislative representative, United Automobile Workers [later part
of the Congress of Industrial Organizations] </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1963</datesingle>
<event>Diagnosed as having chronic bronchitis; Veterans Administration awarded
higher disability pension; emphysema and bronchiectasis claims disallowed as
not service-connected</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1972, Apr. 4</datesingle>
<event>Died, Oaxaca, Mexico</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist>
<head>Claire Sifton </head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1897, Dec. 23</datesingle>
<event>Born, Campos, Rio de Janiero State, Brazil</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1911</fromdate>
<todate>1914</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended Greenville, S.C., Female Seminary, and Hyde Park School, Kansas
City, Mo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1915</fromdate>
<todate>1918</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended Stephens College, Columbia, Mo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>B.A. in journalism, University of Missouri, Columbia, Mo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1920</fromdate>
<todate>1922</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Worked in Chicago, Ill., as feature writer for Montgomery Ward and Co., and
the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Saturday Blade</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1922</datesingle>
<event>Married Paul Field Sifton</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1923</fromdate>
<todate>31</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Worked as feature writer and freelance journalist for the <title localtype="simple">
<part>Public Ledger</part>
</title>, the Fifth Avenue Coach Co., and the New York <title localtype="simple">
<part>Evening World</part>
</title> syndicate, and others</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1929</datesingle>
<event>Published under the name of Claire Morton <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Perfect Baby</part>
</title>. New York: Vanguard Press</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1930</datesingle>
<event>Play written with Paul Field Sifton, <title localtype="simple">
<part>Midnight</part>

West German television play (1957)</event>
</chronitem>

</title>, produced in Boston, Mass., and Baltimore, Md. theaters</event>
</chronitem>

<todate>1942</todate>

</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>

<part>Ernie</part>
</title>, published in the <title localtype="simple">
<part>One Act Play Magazine and Theatre Review</part>
</title> (January 1940)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>

<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>

<part>U.D.A.Congressional Newsletter</part>
</title>, for the Union for Democratic Action</event>

<daterange>
<fromdate>1946</fromdate>
<todate>1948</todate>
</daterange>

U.S. Children's Bureau</event>
</chronitem>

<daterange>

<todate>1962</todate>
</daterange>

</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1980, Feb. 9</datesingle>
<event>Died, Oaxaca, Mexico</event>

<head>Paul Field Sifton </head>

<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1897, Oct. 17</datesingle>
<event>Born, Rockford, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1915</datesingle>
<event>Graduate, Benton Harbor, Mich., high school</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1917</fromdate>
<todate>1919</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Private, first class, Headquarters Company, 6th Field Artillery, 1st
Division, American Expeditionary Forces, invalided out with diagnosis of
pulmonary tuberculosis</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1919</fromdate>
<todate>1920</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Attended University of Missouri, Columbia, Mo., on federal program for
disabled veterans</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1921</datesingle>
<event>Attended London School of Economics, London, England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1922</datesingle>
<event>Married Claire E. Ginsburg</event>
</chronitem>

<todate>1923</todate>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1870, June 25 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Brooklyn, N.Y. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1888</datesingle>
<event>B.A., Columbia University, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1895</fromdate>
<todate>1941</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Ornithologist, 1895-1914; assistant biologist, 1915-1923; biologist,
1924-1928; and senior biologist, 1928-1941; United States Biological Survey,
Washington, D.C. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1904</fromdate>
<todate>1910</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Professor of zoology, Biltmore Forest School, N.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1914</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>M.S., George Washington University, Washington, D.C.</event>
<event>Married Mary Forrest Smith</event>
<event>Professor of ornithology, Pennsylvania Summer School for
Teachers</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1916</datesingle>
<event>Ph.D., George Washington University, Washington, D.C. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1919</fromdate>
<todate>1939</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Lecturer, American School of Wildlife Protection, McGregor, Iowa</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>

</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1945</datesingle>
<event>Named assistant director, Cleveland Public Library, Cleveland, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1947</fromdate>
<todate>1948</todate>
</daterange>
<event>President, Ohio Library Association </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1950</fromdate>
<todate>1954</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Director, Cleveland Public Library, Cleveland, Ohio</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1954</fromdate>
<todate>1955</todate>
</daterange>
<event>President, American Library Association</event>
</chronitem>

<datesingle>1954</datesingle>

</chronitem>

<event>Died, Washington, D.C.</event>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1863</datesingle>
<event>Born, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1882</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, City College of New York, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1896</datesingle>
<event>Became involved in the motion picture business</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1897</datesingle>
<event>Incorporated the George Kleine Optical Co., Chicago, Ill.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1903</datesingle>
<event>Began the importation of foreign films</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1906</datesingle>
<event>Established film rental and selling branches in the United States and
Canada</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1907</datesingle>
<event>Founded, with Samuel Long and Frank J. Marion, the Kalem Co., and served as
first president</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1910</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Published <title localtype="simple">
<part>Catalog of Educational Moving Pictures</part>
</title>. Chicago: Press of Bentley, Murray</event>
<event>Sold his distributing exchanges to the General Film Co., served as vice
president, 1910-1913, and president, 1916</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1913</datesingle>
<event>Imported the Italian film <title localtype="simple">
<part>Quo Vadis?</part>
</title> that became a model for future films</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1916</datesingle>
<event>With others formed the Kleine-Edison-Selig-Essanay Service</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1917</datesingle>
<event>Instituted a new film rental system</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920s</datesingle>
<event>Devoted much time to the development of a system for the distribution of
educational films</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1921</datesingle>
<event>Produced the serial <title localtype="simple">
<part>The Hope Diamond Mystery</part>
</title>
</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1923</datesingle>
<event>Moved to New York, N.Y.; became treasurer and chairman of the board of
directors of Ritz-Carlton Pictures</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1931, June 8</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note for Elizabeth Severn</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1879, Nov. 17</datesingle>
<event>Born Leota Brown, Milwaukee, Wisc. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>circa 1900</datesingle>
<event>Married Charles Kenneth Heywood (separated 1905)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1901</datesingle>
<event>Gave birth to daughter, Margaret</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1906</fromdate>
<todate>1907</todate>
</daterange>
<event>After history of mental and emotional illness, treated for nervous breakdown
by a medical doctor using "power of positive thinking"</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1907</datesingle>
<event>Determined to become a mental healer, she obtained a divorce, changed her name
to Elizabeth Severn, and with her daughter moved to Texas</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>circa 1908</fromdate>
<todate>1912</todate>
</daterange>
<event>"Metaphysician and healer," traveled in the United States, including Colorado,
Nebraska, Texas, and Washington, D.C., seeing patients</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1912</fromdate>
<todate>1914</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Moved to England, started a psychotherapy practice in London</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1913</datesingle>
<event>Published <title>
<part>Psycho-Therapy: Its Doctrine and Practice</part>
</title>. London:
Rider</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1914</fromdate>
<todate>1924</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Returned to the United States and established psychotherapy practice in New
York City; was increasingly troubled herself and sought help from several
psychiatrists, without cure</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1917</datesingle>
<event>Published <title>
<part>The Psychology of Behavior</part>
</title>. New York: Dodd,
Mead</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1924</datesingle>
<event>Traveled to Budapest, Hungary, to undergo analysis with Sándor
Ferenczi</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1924</fromdate>
<todate>1933</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Analysand of Sándor Ferenczi; traveled frequently between Europe and New York
for analysis while continuing her own practices in New York City and London,
England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933</datesingle>
<event>Death of Sándor Ferenczi; Severn resumed her psychotherapy practice in London,
England</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933</datesingle>
<event>Published <title>
<part>The Discovery of the Self</part>
</title>. London: Rider</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1933</fromdate>
<todate>1939</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Traveled between London, England, and New York City; gave lectures and taught
courses on psychology while continuing to see patients</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1939</fromdate>
<todate>1959</todate>
</daterange>
<event>With the advent of World War II, moved permanently to New York City; continued
to write, lecture, and see patients</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1959, Feb.</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
<p>[Biographical note based in part on Christopher Fortune, "The Case of 'RN':
Sándor Ferenczi's Radical Experiment in Psychoanalysis," chapter 6 of <emph render="italic">The Legacy of Sándor Ferenczi</emph>, Lewis Aron and Adrienne
Harris, editors. (New Jersey: Analytic Press, 1993)]</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note for Margaret Severn</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1901, Aug. 14</datesingle>
<event>Born Margaret Heywood, Birmingham, Ala.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1909</datesingle>
<event>First dance performance, Denver, Colo.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1912</fromdate>
<todate>1914</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Lived in London, England, with her mother; studied dance with Eduord
Espinosa</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1914</datesingle>
<event>Moved to New York City, ballet student of Luigi Albertieri</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1916</datesingle>
<event>Summer student of Ruth St. Denis and performer with the Denishawn School of
Dancing, Los Angeles, Calif.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1916</fromdate>
<todate>1931</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Professional dancer in a variety of cabarets, theater revues, and traveling
vaudeville companies</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1920</datesingle>
<event>Performer in the Greenwich Village Follies dancing with masks made by artist
Wladyslaw T. Benda.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1924</fromdate>
<todate>1925</todate>
</daterange>
<event>While traveling on the vaudeville circuit, became intimately involved with
Hungarian violinist Ota Gygi who also became her manager; had abortion in April of
1925</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1926</datesingle>
<event>Traveled to Budapest to visit mother; had several sessions with psychoanalyst
Sándor Ferenczi; relationship with Gygi ended</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1927</fromdate>
<todate>1928</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Returned to U.S.; dancer with traveling company</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1929</fromdate>
<todate>1932</todate>
</daterange>

productions, concerts, and recitals.</event>
</chronitem>

</chronitem>

</chronitem>

<datesingle>1938</datesingle>
<event>Returned to Paris, moved to London; miscellaneous dance engagements</event>

<chronitem>

teach dance</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>

<event>Moved to Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada</event>

<chronitem>

<event>Died, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada</event>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Born in Washington, D.C., March 1, 1856, Philip Lee Phillips was raised in New Orleans
and Georgia before returning with his family to Washington in 1866. His father, Philip
Phillips (1807-1884), served in the House of Representatives from South Carolina before
the Civil War and practiced law there afterwards, including before the Supreme Court as
a prominent local attorney. Phillip Lee Phillips entered Columbia College Law School in
1874, but left school a year later for a position on the staff of the Library of
Congress. In 1879 he was listed as an official cataloger. Prior to that, his salary had
been paid without his knowledge by his father. He soon developed an expertise in
cartography, leading to an appointment in 1897 as superintendent of the Hall of Maps and
Charts in the new Library of Congress building and in 1906 as chief of the Maps and
Charts Division. In 1899 Phillips married Imogen D. Hutchins. He produced numerous
bibliographies and atlases, including the first lists of maps and atlases in the Library
of Congress, where he was employed at the time of his death on January 4, 1924. Among
his principal works were <title>
<part>A List of Geographical Atlases in the Library of
Congress </part>
</title>(4 vols., 1909-1920) and<title>
<part> Lists of Maps of America in the
Library of Congress </part>
</title>(1901).</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Dr. Kaj Aage Strand specialized in positional astronomy, photographic astrometry, and
astrometric instrumentation research. His work focused on the determination of stellar
parallaxes, proper motions of stars, and use of visual and photographic observation of
nearby double stars with an interest in the detection of unseen companion stars in
binary systems and extrasolar planets. He is noted for proposing, designing, and
supervising the construction of the United States Naval Observatory's pioneering 61-Inch
Astrometric Reflector in Flagstaff, Arizona, the first telescope engineered specifically
for astrometric purposes. The 61-Inch reflector surpassed refractors in faint object
measurement and advanced parallax measurement accuracy from hundredths of an arcsecond
to near milliarcseconds. He also designed and supervised the construction of the Strand
Automatic Measuring Machine (SAMM) for precision measurement of the plate material being
produced with the new astrometric reflector. Strand garnered publicity in 1943 after
announcing evidence of a planetary companion in the binary system 61 Cygni AB, which
reopened broad public debate on planetary bodies outside of the solar system. </p>
<p>While serving in the United States Army Air Forces during World War II, Strand flew and
was chief navigator during B-29 test flights. He was in charge of testing new types of
navigation equipment and developing new types of instrumentation for obtaining accurate
ballistic data in aerial bombing. He participated in the operational training of special
air crews, including the crew of the Enola Gay, first to drop the atomic bomb. </p>
<p>Strand served as International Astronomical Union President of Commissions 24
(Photographic Astrometry) and 26 (Double Stars). He sat on advisory panels for the
National Science Foundation, Office of Naval Research, National Research Council,
National Bureau of Standards, and Senior Fulbright-Hays Program Committee. He was
awarded fellowships from the Danish Rask-Oersted Foundation (1938-1940) and the John
Guggenheim Foundation (1946). Samples of Strand's awards include the Distinguished
Service Medal, United States Army Air Forces (1946) and the Knight, 1st Class, Danish
Royal Order of Dannebrog (1977). A minor planet, 3236 Strand = 1982 BH1 was named in his
honor and the 61-Inch Reflector was rededicated and renamed the Kaj Strand Astrometric
Telescope in 1997. </p>
<chronlist>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Louis Nizer, born February 6, 1902, in London, England, was a lawyer and author noted for
advising important people in politics, business, and entertainment, and for defending
unpopular causes and individuals. He successfully represented Quentin Reynolds in his
libel suit against columnist Westbook Pegler and broadcaster John Henry Faulk in a
suit hailed as a critical legal victory against blacklisting. Nizer also wrote
several books, including the best-selling <title>
<part>My Life In Court </part>
</title>(Garden
City, N.Y., 1961), and in 1964, he authored the foreword to the Warren Commission
report that investigated the assassination of John F. Kennedy.</p>
<p>Nizer graduated from Columbia University Law School and in 1924 established with Louis Phillips the legal partnership that became
Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim &amp; Ballon. Prominent clients included Johnny Carson, Charlie Chaplin, Salvador Dali, Mae West,
Julius Erving, and Spyros P. Skouros. Nizer died in New York City, November 10, 1994.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Organizational History</head>
<p>The Elections Research Center was established in 1955 as a branch of the Governmental
Affairs Institute, a nonprofit research and survey organization founded in 1950. After
receiving a grant from the Stern Family Fund, then Chairman of the Board, Edward
Litchfield, invited noted political scientist, Richard M. Scammon, to head the
Institute’s newly formed Elections Office, later known as the Elections Research Center.
The Elections Research Center operated under Scammon’s direction for thirty years,
collecting elections data from each state at the municipal, state, and federal level and
publishing several comprehensive analyses of American voting trends and statistics.
Using the data collected, the Center published its biennial series, <title>
<part>America Votes</part>
</title>, first released in 1956 and thereafter each general election, which
systematically reported voting returns by state. Other works edited by Scammon, with
assistance from his collaborator, Alice B. McGillivray, under the auspices of the
Elections Research Center include <title>
<part>Southern Primaries 58</part>
</title> (1959), <title>
<part>America at the Polls: A Handbook of American Presidential and Election
Statistics, 1920-1964 </part>
</title>(1965), and <title>
<part>America at the Polls: A Handbook of American Presidential and Election
Statistics, 1968-1984</part>
</title> (1988). The Elections Research Center closed in 1995.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Richard Lathers was born in Georgetown, South Carolina, in 1820. He married Abby Thurston Pitman in 1846, and two years later moved to New York. Successful as a banker and merchant, Lathers became director, in 1855, of the New York &amp; Erie Railroad, and subsequently president of the Great Western Insurance Company. He died in New York City, September 17, 1903.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<event>Awarded National Medal of Art</event>

<chronitem>
<datesingle>1990</datesingle>
<event>Retired from Pei Freed Cobb &amp; Partners</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1993</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Medal of Freedom by George H. W. Bush</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>2000</datesingle>
<event>Received Living Legend Award from the Library of Congress</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>2003</datesingle>
<event>Awarded National Design Award for Lifetime Achievement, Smithsonian
Institution, Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>2019, May 16</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<bioghist>
<head>I. M. Pei</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1917, Apr. 26</datesingle>
<event>Born Ieoh Ming Pei, Canton (Guangzhou), China</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1935</datesingle>
<event>Traveled to the United States to study architecture</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1940</datesingle>
<event>B.S. in architecture, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge,
Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942</datesingle>
<event>Married Eileen Loo (died 2014)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1943</fromdate>
<todate>1945</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Operation analyst, National Defense Research Committee</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1945</fromdate>
<todate>1948</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Assistant professor, Harvard University Graduate School of Design,
Cambridge, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946</datesingle>
<event>M.S. in architecture, Harvard University Graduate School of Design,
Cambridge, Mass.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1948</fromdate>
<todate>1955</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Director of architecture, Webb &amp; Knapp, Inc. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1954</datesingle>
<event>Became naturalized citizen of the United States</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1955</fromdate>
<todate>1990</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Founded I. M. Pei &amp; Associates (later I. M. Pei &amp; Partners in 1966,
and Pei Cobb Freed &amp; Partners in 1989)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1964</datesingle>
<event>Elected fellow, American Institute of Architects</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1966</fromdate>
<todate>1970</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Served on the National Council on the Humanities, appointed by Lyndon B.
Johnson</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1967</datesingle>
<event>Elected member, American Academy of Arts and Sciences</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1975</datesingle>
<event>Elected member, American Academy of Arts and Letters</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1975</datesingle>
<event>Elected member, Royal Institute of British Architects</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1979</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Gold Medal, American Institute of Architects</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1980</datesingle>
<event>Appointed member, National Council on the Arts by Jimmy Carter</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1981</datesingle>
<event>Elected member, American Philosophical Society</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1981</fromdate>
<todate>1984</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Member, National Council on the Arts</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1983</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Pritzker Architecture Prize</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1986</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Medal of Liberty by Ronald Reagan</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1988</datesingle>
<event>Awarded National Medal of Art</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1990</datesingle>
<event>Retired from Pei Freed Cobb &amp; Partners</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1993</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Medal of Freedom by George H. W. Bush</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>2000</datesingle>
<event>Received Living Legend Award from the Library of Congress</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>2003</datesingle>
<event>Awarded National Design Award for Lifetime Achievement, Smithsonian
Institution, Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>2019, May 16</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Organizational History</head>
<p>The 92nd Infantry Division and the 93rd Infantry Division were racially segregated units
of the United States Army during World War I and World War II. Nicknamed the "Buffalo
Soldier Division," the 92nd was the only African American division in World War II to
see combat in Europe as part of the Fifth Army. The 93rd Division, known as the "Blue
Helmet" Division, acquired that sobriquet when the division fought in France in World
War I. The 93rd Division served in combat in the Pacific Theater during World War
II.</p>
</bioghist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1888, May 12 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Vienna, Austria </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1910</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Completed undergraduate studies in psychology and literature, University of
Vienna, Vienna, Austria</event>
<event>Met Sigmund Freud</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1911</datesingle>
<event>Admitted to the Vienna Psychoanalytic Society</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1912</datesingle>
<event>PhD, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1914</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Married Eleanore (“Ella”) Oratsch (died 1934)</event>
<event>Moved to Berlin, Germany, to begin analysis with Karl Abraham</event>
<event>Received the first award in applied psychoanalysis for his essay “The
Puberty Rites of Savages,” <title render="italic">
<part>Imago, </part>
</title> vol. 4 (1915): 189-222</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1915</fromdate>
<todate>1918</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Served in World War I</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1918</datesingle>
<event>Returned to Vienna, Austria</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1928</datesingle>
<event>Moved to Berlin, Germany</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1934</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Moved to The Hague, Netherlands</event>
<event>Married Marija Cubelic (died 1960)</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1938</datesingle>
<event>Immigrated to the United States, settling in New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1944</datesingle>
<event>Became a United States citizen</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1948</datesingle>
<event>Founded the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysts</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1953</datesingle>
<event>Published <title render="italic">
<part>The Haunting Melody</part>
</title> (New York: Farrar, Straus, and Young)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1957</datesingle>
<event>Published <title render="italic">
<part>Of Love and Lust: On the Psychoanalysis of Romantic and Sexual
Emotions</part>
</title> (New York: Farrar, Straus, and Giroux) </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1962</datesingle>
<event>Published <title render="italic">
<part>Jewish Wit</part>
</title> (New York: Gamut Press)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1963</datesingle>
<event>Published <title render="italic">
<part>The Need to Be Loved</part>
</title> (New York: Farrar, Straus, and Co.)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1964</datesingle>
<event>Published <title render="italic">
<part>Pagan Rites in Judaism</part>
</title> (New York: Farrar, Straus, and Co.)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1966</datesingle>
<event>Published <title render="italic">
<part>The Many Faces of Sex</part>
</title> (New York: Farrar, Straus, and Giroux)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1969, Dec. 31</datesingle>
<event>Died, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Organizational History</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>
<head01>Date</head01>
<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1979 </datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Established in Washington D.C. as a progressive, environmentalist, and
liberal political party</event>
<event>Registered with the Federal Elections Commission </event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1980</datesingle>
<event>Held first national convention in Cleveland, Ohio, where delegates nominated
Barry Commoner for President and LaDonna Harris for Vice President</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1981</datesingle>
<event>Terry Bouricius is first party candidate to win an election when elected to
the Board of Aldermen in Burlington, Vt. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1984</datesingle>
<event>Held second national convention in St. Paul, Minn., where delegates nominated
Sonia Johnson for president and Richard Walton for vice president </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1987</datesingle>
<event>Disbanded after low votes cast for party nominees in 1986 elections </event>
</chronitem>
</chronlist>
</bioghist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>
<listhead>

<head02>Event</head02>
</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1933, 20 Apr.</datesingle>
<event>Born, New York, N.Y. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1953</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1959</fromdate>
<todate>1961</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Special Assistant in the White House Office</event>
</chronitem>

<datesingle>1969</datesingle>
<event>Deputy Assistant to the President for Urban Affairs</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1969</fromdate>
<todate>1971</todate>
</daterange>
<event>National Chairman of the White House Conference on Children and

</chronitem>

<event>Joined the Brookings Institution, Washington, D.C.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1974</datesingle>
<event>United States representative to the Unesco General Conference</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1976</datesingle>
<event>United States representative to the United Nations General
Assembly</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1979</fromdate>
<todate>1982</todate>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Administrative History</head>
<p>
<emph render="italic">Look</emph> was a biweekly, general interest popular magazine
published from March 1937 to October 1971 by Gardner Cowles, Jr., under various company
names: <emph render="italic">Look</emph>, Inc. (1937-1945); Cowles Magazines
(1946-1965); and Cowles Communications, Inc. (1965-1971). <emph render="italic">Look</emph> began as a tabloid-style magazine that emphasized sports, movie stars,
and sensationalism. After World War II, it became more family oriented and included
articles on social and political subjects, as well as regular features on personalities,
food, fashion, and sports. <emph render="italic">Look's</emph> "golden years"
(1954-1964) followed improvements in the magazine's design and focus by editor Fleur
Cowles, art director Alan Hurlburt, managing editor Dan Mich, and others.</p>
<p>
<emph render="italic">Courtesy of the Prints and Photographs Division, Library of
Congress (http://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/lmc/background.html)</emph>
</p>
</bioghist>

<head>Biographical Note</head>
<chronlist>

</listhead>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1926, June 29 </datesingle>
<event>Born, Bryn Mawr, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1944, June</datesingle>
<event>Graduated, Lower Merion High School, Ardmore, Pa.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1943-1944</datesingle>
<event>Enlisted, United States Army Air Corps Enlisted Reserve and entered active
duty as a private, Keesler Air Force Base, Biloxi, Miss. </event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1944, Dec.-1945, Aug.</datesingle>
<event>Officer Candidate School, Fort Benning, Ga.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1945, Aug. 16</datesingle>
<event>Commissioned a second lieutenant of Infantry, United States Army</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1945, Oct.-Dec.</datesingle>
<event>Platoon leader and executive officer, 369th Infantry Regiment, 93rd Infantry
Division, Morotai, South Pacific Theater</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1946</datesingle>
<event>Platoon leader, 542nd Heavy Construction Company, detailed to the Signal
Corps, Philippines</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1947-1948</datesingle>
<event>Promoted first lieutenant, Signal Corps.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1948, Jan. 29</datesingle>
<event>Married Louise A. Thornton</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1948</datesingle>
<event>Recalled to active duty as a second lieutenant, Signal Corps, Fort Monmouth,
N.J.</event>
</chronitem>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Reverend Stephen Donald Pyle (1888-1969) was a Baptist minister in Rock Springs, Wyoming. Born in Virginia on September 13, 1888, he graduated from Brown University in 1910 and received a master’s degree in religious education from Columbia University. In the 1930s, Pyle was the pastor of the Peking United Church in Beijing, China. After retirement, Pyle moved to Oakland, California, where he died on January 3, 1969.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note for George S. Koyl and Moira B. Mathieson</head>
<p> George S. Koyl was born February 8, 1885, in Evanston, Wyoming. He studied
architecture at the University of Pennsylvania and the American Academy in Rome. He
worked as an architect in Colorado and New York, and later opened up his own
independent firm. He then partnered with the firm Rich, Mathesius &amp; Koyl in
1929. He left the firm in 1932 to work as the Dean of the School of Fine Arts at the
University of Pennsylvania. He retired in 1950 and worked as a professor of
architecture until 1955. Koyl was the president of the American Institute of
Architects (AIA) chapter in Pennsylvania from 1943 to 1944 and served on its
executive committee from 1943 to 1946.</p>
<p> Moira B. Mathieson was born around 1924. She became a freelance writer and editor
after a career in architecture and art history. From 1963 to 1969, she was the Head
of Architectural Drawings Project, Department of Civil History at the Smithsonian
Institution. Together, Koyl and Mathieson compiled and edited <emph render="italic">American Architectural Drawings: a Catalog of Original and Measured Drawings of
Buildings of the United States of America to December 31, 1917</emph> (1969),
which was funded by a Kress Foundation grant and prepared and published through the
Philadelphia Chapter of the AIA. </p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

<head>Biographical Notes</head>

<chronlist>

<chronitem>
<datesingle>1921, Dec. 2</datesingle>
<event>Born Isabella Helen Lugoski, Detroit, Mich.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1941</datesingle>
<event>B.S., chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1942</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>M.S., physical chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor,
Mich.</event>
<event>Married Jerome Karle (died 2013)</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1944</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>Ph.D., physical chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor,
Mich.</event>
<event>Research Associate, Manhattan Project, University of Chicago,
Chicago, Ill.</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1944</fromdate>
<todate>1946</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Chemistry instructor, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor,
Mich.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<daterange>
<fromdate>1946</fromdate>
<todate>2009</todate>
</daterange>
<event>Physicist, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. (Head of
Laboratory for the Structure of Matter X-Ray Analysis Section beginning
in 1968)</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1965</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Navy Superior Civilian Service Award</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1968</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Society of Women Engineers Annual Achievement Award</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1970</datesingle>
<event>Awarded American Chemical Society Hillebrand Prize</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1973</datesingle>
<event>Awarded Federal Woman’s Award</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1976</datesingle>
<chronitemset>
<event>President, American Crystallographic Association</event>
<event>Awarded American Chemical Society Garvan Medal</event>
</chronitemset>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1978</datesingle>
<event>Elected to National Academy of Sciences</event>

<bioghist encodinganalog="545">
<head>Biographical Note</head>
<p>Ara Mesrobian was born August 7, 1924, in Washington, D.C. He attended Catholic
University, graduating with a degree in electrical engineering in 1950 after serving
in World War II in the Pacific Theater. He worked for the National Bureau of
Standards for thirty years. In his free time, Mesrobian pursued his passion for
photography and rail transportation, traveling widely to ride, photograph, and film
trains. He was a member of the National Railway Historical Society (NRHS) for
seventy years and was a founding member of the Potomac Chapter of the NRHS. He also
participated in the Tractioneers, a Washington, D.C.-based organization devoted to
trolleys and light-rail transportation. Mesrobian died June 18, 2019, in Chevy
Chase, Md.</p>
</bioghist>
<bioghist encodinganalog="545">

</chronitem>
<chronitem>

<event>B.A., Queens College, Queens, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>
<datesingle>1968-1970 </datesingle>
<event>Pollster and computer analyst, NBC News, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>
<chronitem>

<event>Computer programmer, New York Stock Exchange, New York, N.Y.</event>
</chronitem>

campaign</event>

<event>Died, Ipswich, Mass.</event>
